PREFACE
         This code of the City of Perkins, as supplemented, contains ordinances
up to and including ordinance 513, passed May 13, 2025. Ordinances of the City
adopted after said ordinance supersede the provisions of this code to the
extent that they are in conflict or inconsistent therewith. Consult the City
office in order to ascertain whether any particular provision of the code has
been amended, superseded or repealed.
                           American Legal Publishing
                           Cincinnati, Ohio
ORDINANCES PENDING REVIEW FOR CODIFICATION
Listed ordinances have been passed, but they are pending review by the
publisher, and they may not amend the code of ordinances. Additionally,
ordinances listed in this section may not show the original ordinances in their
entirety. Please contact the office of the clerk if there are any questions
concerning any listed ordinances.
ADOPTING ORDINANCE
ORDINANCE NO. 394
"AN ORDINANCE ADOPTING A CODE OF ORDINANCES FOR THE CITY OF PERKINS, OKLAHOMA
AND REPEALING PERMANENT AND GENERAL ORDINANCES NOT INCLUDED IN THE CODE."
   BE IT ORDAINED BY THE CITY COMMISSIONERS OF THE CITY OF PERKINS, STATE OF
OKLAHOMA:
   SECTION 1: Code Adopted: How Cited. The code of ordinances entitled "Perkins
City Code, 2012", compiled, arranged and codified by Sterling Codifiers, is
hereby adopted for the city of Perkins, Oklahoma, and shall go into effect at
the same time this ordinance goes into effect. Said code may be cited as
"Perkins City Code, 2012", "Perkins City Code", or other appropriate
designations.
   SECTION 2: Ordinance Provisions Adopted. All of the ordinances provisions
included in the said code are hereby adopted and enacted and shall be in full
effect whether, (1) such provisions are included in the form as originally
adopted, (2) are included therein in amended form, or (3) composed wholly or
partially of new material as authorized by law.
   SECTION 3: Permanent And General Ordinances Not Included, Repealed. All of
the ordinances and parts of ordinances of a permanent and general nature in
effect at the time this code is adopted, but not included in this code, are
hereby repealed as of the time when this code goes into effect.
   SECTION 4: Temporary And/Or Special Ordinances Continued In Effect, Although
Omitted From The Code. The continuance and effect of temporary and/or special
ordinances or parts of ordinances, although omitted from this code, shall not
be effected by such omission therefrom; and the adoption of this code shall not
repeal or amend any such ordinance or part of any such ordinance omitted
therefrom. Among the temporary and/or special ordinances not repealed or
amended by the adoption of this code are the following: ordinances relating to
specific paving and sewer districts and special assessments; vacating, opening
and dedicating specific streets and alleys, relating to specific bond issues;
annexing territory to or excluding it from, the city; relating to grade and
alignment of specific streets; granting railroads use of specific streets and
alleys; naming, or changing the name of, specific streets; abating specific
nuisances; and all other temporary and/or special ordinances. Ordinances
granting franchises shall not be repealed or amended by the adoption of this
code.
   SECTION 5: Emergency Clause. It being immediately necessary for the
preservation of the peace, health and safety, an emergency is hereby declared
to exist by reason whereof this ordinance shall take effect and be in full
force and in effect from and after its passage, approval and publication.
   PASSED, APPROVED AND ADOPTED this 11th day of September, 2012.
       /s/   
      ROBERT JOHNSON, MAYOR
      CITY OF PERKINS, OKLAHOMA

         CITY OF PERKINS, OKLAHOMA
CHARTER
of the City of
PERKINS, OKLAHOMA
PREAMBLE
We, the people of the city of Perkins, Oklahoma, exercising the powers of home
rule granted to us by the constitution and laws of the state of Oklahoma, in
order to provide for more efficient, adequate and economical government, do
hereby ordain, ratify and establish this charter of the city of Perkins,
Oklahoma.
ARTICLE I. INCORPORATION, FORM OF GOVERNMENT, POWERS
Section 1-1. Incorporation
The city of Perkins, Oklahoma, within the corporate limits as now established
or as hereafter may be established, shall continue to be a municipal body
politic and corporate in perpetuity under the name of the "city of Perkins,
Oklahoma". It shall succeed to and possess all the property, rights,
privileges, franchises, powers and immunities now belonging to the corporation
known as the city of Perkins, Oklahoma; and shall be liable for all debts and
other obligations for which the corporation is legally bound at the time this
charter goes into effect.
Section 1-2. Form Of Government
The municipal government provided by this charter shall be known as the
"commission-manager government". All powers of the city shall be exercised in
the manner prescribed by this charter, or, if the manner is not thus
prescribed, then in such manner as the commission may prescribe by ordinance.
Section 1-3. Powers Of The City
The city shall have all powers, functions, rights, privileges, franchises and
immunities granted to cities by the state constitution and law, and all the
implied powers necessary to carry into execution all the powers granted. Except
as prohibited by the state constitution and law, the city shall have all
municipal powers, functions, rights, privileges, franchises and immunities of
every name and nature whatsoever.
The city of Perkins shall have power to adopt a corporate seal and to alter it
at pleasure, to sue and to be sued, and to make contracts. It shall have power
to acquire property within or without its corporate limits for any city
purpose, including public utilities, works and ways, in fee simple or any
lesser interest or estate, by purchase, gift, devise, lease, condemnation or
other legal means; and to hold, maintain, improve, enlarge, manage, control,
operate, lease, sell, convey or otherwise dispose of, such property as its
interest may require, including public utilities, works and ways. It shall have
power to issue bonds in the manner and within the limitations prescribed by the
state constitution and law. It shall have power, within the limits prescribed
by the state constitution and law, to accept and administer federal and state
grants- in-aid and to do everything necessary to accomplish the purpose or
purposes for which such grants may be made. It shall have power to ordain and
to enforce local legislation, consistent with the state constitution and law,
for the proper organization and functioning of the city government, for the
preservation and enforcement of good government and order, for the protection
of health, life, and property, for the prevention, summary abatement and
removal of nuisances, and otherwise for the promotion of the common welfare. It
shall have power to grant, extend and renew franchises in accordance with the
state constitution and law.
The enumeration or mention of particular powers by this charter shall not be
deemed to be exclusive or limiting; and in addition to the powers enumerated or
mentioned herein or implied hereby, the city shall have all powers which, under
the state constitution and law, it would be competent for this charter
specifically to enumerate or mention.
Provisions of state law relating to matters which may be regulated by cities
operating under charters, shall be in effect only insofar as they are
applicable and are not superseded by this charter or by ordinance.
Section 1-4. Bequests, Gifts And Donations
The city of Perkins may receive bequests, gifts and donations of all kinds of
property in fee simple or in trust for charitable or public purposes and
perform all acts necessary to carry out the purposes of such bequests, gifts,
donations or trusts with power to manage, sell, lease, or otherwise dispose of
same in accordance with the terms of the bequest, gift, donation or trust.
Section 1-5. General Grant Of Powers Not Limited
The legislative, executive and judicial powers of the city of Perkins shall
extend to all matters of local and municipal government, it being the intent
hereof that the specification of particular powers by any other provision of
this charter shall never be construed as limiting or impairing the effect of
the general grant of powers hereby made.
Section 1-6. Former Government In Force
All existing ordinances of the city of Perkins not inconsistent with this
charter or inapplicable under the altered form of municipal government provided
by this charter shall be and continue in full force and effect until amended or
repealed or until they expire by their own limitations, and no existing right,
action (civil or penal), court proceeding or contract, shall be affected by the
change in the form of government of the city; but shall all continue as though
no such change had taken place; and all debts, penalties and forfeitures which
have accrued, or which may hereafter accrue by virtue of anything heretofore
done or existing shall inure to the benefit of the city of Perkins and may be
sued for and recovered by the said city as though this charter had not been
adopted. Nothing here, however, shall legalize any invalid indebtedness of the
city heretofore contracted or incurred, or impair any defense, against the
payment of the same; nor shall the adoption of this charter in any way
interfere with any proceedings heretofore instituted relating to the levy and
collection of taxes, special assessments, or levies of any nature or with any
proceedings to enforce the payment of the same, and all contracts heretofore
entered into by the city shall remain in full force and effect and be completed
under the ordinances existing at the time of the adoption of this charter.
Section 1-7. Succession Of Property Ownership
The city of Perkins shall have perpetual succession and shall own, possess and
hold all property, real and personal heretofore owned, possessed or held by the
said city of Perkins and shall assume, manage and dispose of all trusts in any
way connected therewith.
Section 1-8. Succession Of Powers
The city of Perkins shall succeed to all the property rights and liabilities
and shall acquire all benefits, and shall assume and pay all bonds, legal
obligations, and indebtedness of said city of Perkins, and by that name sue and
be sued, may contract and be contracted with, plead and be impleaded,
intervene, prosecute and defend, in all courts and in all matters and
proceedings; and shall have power to acquire property, real and personal, by
purchase or otherwise, within or outside of the city limits, necessary for the
public good, and to own, hold, sell, lease, convey or otherwise dispose of any
real or personal property, within or outside of the city limits.
Section 1-9. Condemnation Powers
The city of Perkins shall have the power, within or without its territorial
limits, to construct, condemn and purchase, acquire, lease, add to, maintain,
conduct and operate, waterworks, light plants, power plants, hospitals,
airports, transportation system, heating plants, cemeteries, parks, community
buildings and convention halls, sewers, and all other public utilities or works
local in use, and to do every other thing required (in whole or in part) for
the use of said city and the inhabitants thereof.
Section 1-10. Succession Of Records
The city of Perkins shall succeed to, own, possess and control all of the
books, records, documents, and all other property, real, personal or mixed,
together with all choses in action and claims belonging to and possessed by the
said city of Perkins, prior to and at the time of the adoption of this charter.
It shall be subject to and liable for all legal debts, obligations, judgments,
warrants and bonds, for which said city is bound at the time this charter shall
become effective.
ARTICLE II. THE COMMISSION
Section 2-1. Commission Created, Number
The elective officers of the city of Perkins shall be a mayor and four
commissioners. All legislative powers except the initiative and referendum
shall be vested in a commission, consisting of a mayor, elected from the city
at large, and four commissioners, each of whom shall be elected at large from
their respective wards to respective commission positions designated as
positions no. 1, 2, 3, and 4.
Section 2-2. Commission Qualifications
Only qualified registered voters of the city of Perkins who have been
registered to vote within the city of Perkins for a period of six (6) months
immediately preceding the date of filing shall be qualified for the offices of
mayor and commissioners and they shall have these qualifications from and after
the time when they file for office or are selected to fill vacancies. If the
mayor or any commissioner ceases to be a resident of the city of Perkins, such
officer shall thereupon immediately cease to be a member of the board of
commissioners. Neither the mayor nor any other commissioner may hold any office
or position in the city government by virtue of appointment by the city
manager. No person, whether such person be the mayor or commissioner, shall
hold office for a period of longer than two (2) consecutive full three (3) year
terms of office which term shall not include the time served in filling any
unexpired term of office.
Section 2-3. Election
A general city election shall be held in said city on the date established by
the general election laws of the state of Oklahoma, or in the absence of such
legislation, by ordinance, at which time there shall be elected a mayor, and
four commissioners to succeed the officers of said city then holding office,
and who shall assume their duties on the first Monday in May following their
election.
The terms of office of those persons chosen in 2001 to commission positions two
(2) and four (4) shall expire at 7:30 P.M. on the first Monday following the
election and certificate of successors to commission positions two (2) and four
(4) in the year 2002 general municipal election; thereafter, the terms of
persons chosen in 2002 and later years to represent wards two (2) and four (4),
shall expire at the time fixed by section 5-1 hereof, such being on the first
Monday following election and certification every three years.
The terms of office of those persons chosen in 2001 to commission positions one
(1) and three (3) shall expire at 7:30 P.M. on the first Monday following the
election and certification of successors to commission positions one (1) and
three (3) in the year 2003 general municipal election; thereafter, the terms of
persons chosen in 2003 and later years to represent wards one (1) and three
(3), shall expire at the time fixed on the first Monday following election and
certification of such commissioners every three years.
The terms of office of the person chosen in 2001 to the office of mayor shall
expire at 7:30 on the first Monday following the election and certification of
the successor to the office of mayor in the year 2004 general municipal
election; thereafter, the term of mayor shall expire at the time fixed on the
first Monday following election and certification of a mayor every three years.
The numbering of city wards shall be determined by the drawing of lots, to be
done by the incumbent mayor in an open public meeting prior to the filing
period for the city elections of 2001. Each elected officer shall continue to
hold and to perform the duties of office until the successor to such office is
elected and qualified, unless such officer is removed or forfeits office under
other provisions of this charter.
Section 2-4. Commission: Powers
Except as otherwise provided in this charter, all powers of the city,
including, the determination of all matters of policy, shall be vested in the
commission. Without limitation of the foregoing, the commission shall have the
power:
(1) To appoint and remove the city manager, the city attorney, and the
municipal judge as provided in this charter;
(2) By ordinance to enact municipal legislation;
(3) To raise revenue and make appropriations, and to regulate bond elections,
the issuance of bonds, sinking funds, the refunding of indebtedness, salaries
and wages, and all other fiscal affairs of the city, subject to the provisions
of the state constitution and the law of this charter;
(4) To inquire into the conduct of any office, department or agency of the
city, and to investigate municipal affairs;
(5) To appoint or elect and remove the members of the library board, parks and
recreation board, planning commission, the members of the board of adjustment
and other quasi-legislative, quasi-judicial or advisory offices and
authorities, now or when and if established, or to prescribe the method of
appointing or electing and removing them;
(6) To regulate elections and the initiative and referendum within the limits
prescribed by the state constitution and the law of this charter;
(7) To create and define the powers of the municipal court within the limits
prescribed by the state constitution and the law of this charter;
(8) To create, change and abolish all offices, departments and agencies of the
city government other than the offices, departments and agencies created by
this charter; and to assign additional powers, duties and functions to offices,
departments and agencies created by this charter;
(9) To establish or adopt a pension, retirement and/or social security system
or systems for any or all groups of the officers and employees in the service
of the city;
(10) To grant pardons, including the remission of fines and costs;
(11) To adopt a corporate seal and alter it at pleasure.
Section 2-5. Commission Not To Interfere In Appointments And Removals
Neither the commission, the mayor nor any of its other members may direct or
request the appointment of any person to, or removal from office or employment
by the city manager or by any other authority, or, except as provided in this
charter, participate in any manner in the appointment or removal of officers
and employees of the city. Except for the purpose of inquiry, the commission,
the mayor and its other members shall deal with the employees of the city of
Perkins solely through the city manager; and neither the commission, the mayor
nor any other member thereof may give orders on administrative matters to any
subordinate of the city manager either publicly or privately.
Section 2-6. Library Board
There shall be a library board, which shall be head of the library department.
It shall consist of five (5) members appointed by the city commission for
overlapping terms of three (3) years and to serve until their respective
successors have been appointed and qualify. The terms of two (2) members shall
begin at 7:30 o'clock P.M. on the first Monday in May in every year except
every third year when the term of only one (1) member shall begin.
Every year, at the time prescribed for the beginning of the terms of new
members or as soon thereafter as practicable, the library board shall elect a
chairman, a vice chairman and a secretary. It shall determine the time and
place of its regular meetings; and the chairman or any four (4) members may
call special meetings of the board.
The library board shall have supervision and control of the public library or
libraries of the city subject to budget appropriations of the city commission.
The library board may adopt regulations for the administration and operation of
the library or libraries, subject to ordinances which the commission may enact.
Section 2-7. Parks And Recreation Board
There shall be a parks and recreation board. The parks and recreation board
shall have responsibility for all recreation activity and all park areas within
the city of Perkins. The parks and recreation board shall consist of not less
than five (5) nor more than seven (7) members appointed by the city commission
and each of whom shall serve overlapping three (3) year terms. The city
commission, by ordinance, shall determine qualifications, rules, and procedures
for the parks and recreation board.
Section 2-8. City Clerk
The director of finance, herein provided for, shall be appointed by the city
manager, subject to approval of the city commission and also be ex officio city
clerk unless the commission by ordinance provides that the commission shall
appoint the city clerk for an indefinite term.
The city clerk shall serve as clerical officer of the commission. The city
clerk shall keep the journal of its proceedings, and shall enroll in a book or
books kept for the purpose all ordinances and resolutions passed by it. The
city clerk shall be custodian of such documents, records and archives as may be
provided by applicable law or ordinance; shall be custodian of the seal of the
city; and shall attest, and affix the seal to documents when required in
accordance with applicable law or ordinance.
Section 2-9. Mayor And Vice Mayor
The mayor shall preside at meetings of the commission, and shall certify the
passage of all ordinances and resolutions passed by it. The mayor shall be
recognized as the head of the city government for all ceremonial purposes and
by the governor for purposes of military law. The mayor shall have no regular
administrative duties except that the mayor shall sign such written obligations
of the city as the commission may require. As a commissioner, the mayor shall
have all powers, rights, privileges, duties and responsibilities of a
commissioner, including the right to vote on questions.
At the first meeting after the time prescribed for the beginning of the term of
a newly elected mayor or commissioners, or as soon thereafter as practicable,
the commission shall elect from its membership a vice mayor, who shall serve
until the time prescribed for the beginning of the term of the next newly
elected mayor or commissioners and until a successor has been elected and
qualifies. The vice mayor shall act as mayor during the absence, disability or
suspension of the mayor, or, if a vacancy occurs in the office of mayor, until
another mayor is elected by the commission and qualifies. If the office of vice
mayor becomes vacant, the commission shall elect from its membership another
vice mayor.
Section 2-10. Commission: Meetings
The commission shall hold at least one (1) regular meeting every month at such
time as it may prescribe by ordinance or otherwise. The mayor or any three (3)
commissioners may call special meetings. All meetings of the commission shall
be open to the public, except those private meetings allowed by state law, and
the journal of proceedings shall be open to public inspection.
Section 2-11. Commission: Absences To Terminate Membership
If the mayor or any other commissioner shall be absent from more than one- half
of all the meetings of the commission, regular and special, held within any
period of four (4) consecutive calendar months, such officer shall thereupon
cease to hold office.
Section 2-12. Commissioners: Removal and Recall
(1)   Commissioners; Removal
The mayor or any commissioner shall be subject to removal from office in the
manner and for the same cause or causes as provided by the laws of the state of
Oklahoma for the removal of county officers, it being intended hereby to
provide cumulative procedure and cause for removal. In the event of a vacancy
in the office of mayor, the vice mayor shall serve as mayor with all the powers
and duties vested in the mayor until such vacancy is filled as provided for by
appointment or election as provided herein.
(2)   Commission Subject to Recall
Any holder of elective City office, including a person appointed to fill a
vacancy in any such office, may be recalled at any time by the electors
qualified to vote for the successor of such office holder in the manner
provided herein. Provided that no such office holder shall be removed from
office by recall until he shall have held such office for a period of time
greater than six (6) months. After one recall petition and election, no further
recall petition shall be filed against the same office holder during the term
for which he was elected, unless petitioners filing such petition shall first
pay into the City treasury an amount equal to all expenses of the preceding
election incurred by the City.
(3)   Initiating Recall Proceedings and Petition
To initiate recall proceedings, a written statement, in duplicate, proposing
the recall of the office holder shall be signed by one hundred (100) or more
registered, qualified electors of the City of Perkins, and shall be filed with
the City Clerk. The statement shall contain the reason, or reasons, for which
recall is sought, such statement in two hundred (200) words or less. Within
five (5) business days, the City Clerk shall mail a copy of such statement by
registered, certified or similar special mail to the official sought to be
recalled at his or her residential address. Said officer shall have ten (10)
business days after mailing of such statement to formulate and deliver to the
City Clerk a statement of not more than two hundred (200) words setting forth
the reason, or reasons, justifying such officer's conduct in office. When the
ten (10) business day period for response on the part of the office holder has
expired, the persons desiring said recall shall file with the City Clerk a
petition for the recall of such officer. Said petition shall contain in the
heading thereof the reasons for the recall as stated in the statement filed,
and the reasons justifying such officer's conduct in office, if the office
holder shall have filed any such reasons within the ten (10) business day
period. Said petition shall be filed with the City Clerk prior to circulation.
(4)   Requirements of Petition
At least two hundred (200) registered qualified electors of the City of Perkins
or the number of registered qualified electors of the City of Perkins equal to
twenty-five percent (25%) of the total electors voting at the last preceding
City general election, whichever is greater, must sign the petition. Each
signer shall write after his name his address within the City of Perkins,
giving street or avenue, if any. Not more than twenty-five (25) signatures may
appear on a single copy of the petition. Petitions shall be circulated only by
registered qualified electors of the City and the person who circulates each
copy of the petition shall sign an affidavit on the copy of the petition
stating each signer thereof signed the petition in his presence, that each
signature on the petition is genuine and that he believes each signer to be a
registered qualified elector of the City.
(5)   City Clerk to Determine Sufficiency of Petition
The circulated petition shall be filed with the City Clerk not later than one
month after the filing of a copy as provided above. Within one month after date
of filing the circulated petition, the City Clerk shall examine it and
ascertain whether it has been prepared and circulated as required and whether
the required number of registered qualified electors of the City of Perkins
have signed it. The City Clerk shall then attach a certificate to the petition.
If the City Clerk certifies that the petition has not been prepared and
circulated as required and/or lacks a sufficient number of signatures, the
petition shall have no effect; but if the City Clerk certifies that the
petition has been prepared and circulated as required and has a sufficient
number of signatures, he shall submit the petition and certificate to the City
Commission at its next meeting.
(6)   Date of Recall Election
The Commission, by resolution, after receiving the petition and certificate of
the City Clerk, shall order and fix a date for the recall election. Such
election shall be held not less than sixty (60), nor more than one hundred
twenty (120), days after the passage of the resolution. The City Clerk shall
cause the resolution ordering the election to be published in full in a
newspaper of general circulation within the City, within ten (10) days after
its passage and such publication shall be sufficient notice of the election.
(7)   Multiple Recalls
If more than one elected official is sought to be recalled, then and in that
event, separate petitions shall be filed and circulated as hereinbefore
provided for each such official.
(8)   Results of Recall
There shall be no primary election. The recall election shall be an election to
fill the office or offices held by the incumbent or incumbents sought to be
recalled. Any qualified person, including the incumbent or incumbents, may file
as a candidate for the office or offices. The candidate or candidates receiving
the greatest number of votes for the office or offices in the recall election
shall be elected. If at such election, some person or persons other than the
incumbent or incumbents receives the highest number of votes, the said
incumbent or incumbents shall be deemed to have been removed, and shall vacate
the office after qualification of his successor, which shall be within ten (10)
days from declaration of the result, otherwise the incumbent shall remain in
office.
(9)   Charter to Govern Recall Elections
The provisions of this Charter relating to City's elections shall govern recall
elections insofar as they are applicable to and are not superseded by the
provisions of this Charter.
(10)   Recalled Official Not to Hold Office or Employment
No person who has been recalled from an office or has resigned from such
office, while recall proceedings are pending against him may hold any office or
position of employment in City government of the City of Perkins within four
(4) years after his/her recall or resignation. (Res. 1-2022, 2-1-2022, Election
held 4-5-2022)
Section 2-13. Commission: Vacancies
The commission, by majority vote of its remaining members, shall fill vacancies
in its own membership, including the office of mayor, for the unexpired terms
or until successors are elected as provided in this section. If a vacancy
occurs before the beginning of a regular filing period for candidates for mayor
or commissioner, and the unexpired term extends beyond 7:30 o'clock P.M. on the
next first Monday in May, then a mayor or commissioner for that place shall be
elected at the elections of that year to serve the rest of the unexpired term
beginning at 7:30 o'clock P.M. on said first Monday following election and
certification of such commissioner.
If the commission fails to call a special election or fails to fill a vacancy
in its membership within sixty (60) days after the vacancy begins, then the
mayor or acting mayor shall issue a proclamation calling a special election to
fill the vacancy for the unexpired term. Any special election held under this
section shall be held not less than thirty (30) days nor more than forty (40)
days after issuance of the proclamation. There shall be no primary election for
this purpose. The candidate receiving the greatest number of votes at the
election shall be elected, and shall serve for the unexpired term. The
provisions of this charter relating to regular elections shall govern such
special elections insofar as they are applicable. After issuance of such
proclamation, the commission may not fill the vacancy.
Section 2-14. Commission: Quorum, Rules, Yeas And Nays
A majority of all the members of the commission shall constitute a quorum, but
a smaller number may adjourn from day to day or from time to time. The
commission may determine its own rules of procedure and order.
Section 2-15. Mayor And Commissioners Prohibited From Appointment
Neither the mayor nor any commissioner shall be appointed to any office created
by the mayor and commission during the term of office of such officer until the
expiration of one year after completion of the term of office of such
commissioner.
Section 2-16. Former Officers Retained
All officers, appointees, and employees of the present corporation of the city
of Perkins, except the mayor, city clerk, city treasurer and councilmen, shall
continue in their respective offices and employment upon adoption of this
charter and the organization of the new city government until their services
are dispensed with by order of the commission or the city manager. The
commission shall by majority vote fill all vacancies where this charter
provides for appointments to be made by the commission; the city manager shall
fill all vacancies where this charter provides for the appointment to be made
by the city manager.
ARTICLE III. CITY MANAGER AND ADMINISTRATIVE DEPARTMENTS
Section 3-1. City Manager: Appointment, Terms, Qualifications, Removal
There shall be a city manager. The commission shall appoint the city manager
for an indefinite term by a vote of a majority of all its members. It shall
choose the city manager solely on the basis of executive and administrative
qualifications. At the time of appointment, such person need not be a resident
of the city or state; but, within one year of taking office, the board of
commissioners may require that such person live within a five (5) mile radius
of the corporate limits of the city of Perkins and continue to reside in such
area during the city manager's term of office. Neither the mayor nor any other
commissioner may be appointed city manager or acting city manager during the
term for which such person shall have been elected nor within one (1) year
after the expiration of his term. The commission may suspend or remove the city
manager at any time by a vote of a majority of all its members.
Section 3-2. Acting City Manager
If the city manager is absent from the city or is unable to perform the duties
of city manager, if the commission suspends the city manager, or if there is a
vacancy in the office of city manager, the commission may appoint an acting
city manager, for a period of time not to exceed one (1) year, to serve until
the city manager returns, until such disability or suspension ceases, or until
another city manager is appointed and qualifies, as the case may be. The
commission may suspend or remove an acting city manager at any time.
Section 3-3. City Manager: Powers And Duties
The city manager shall be chief administrative officer and head of the
administrative branch of the city government. The city manager shall execute
the laws and ordinances and administer the government of the city, and shall be
responsible therefor to the commission. The city manager shall:
(1) Appoint department heads of the city, subject to approval of the city
commission, appoint all other employees of the city, and when deemed necessary
for the good of the service, lay off, suspend, demote or remove the librarian,
all directors, or heads, of administrative departments and all other
administrative officers and employees of the city except personnel in the
office of the city attorney, except the city manager or the commission by
ordinance or this charter may authorize the head of a department, an officer or
an agency to appoint, lay off, suspend, demote and/or remove subordinates in
such department, office or agency;
(2) Supervise and control, directly or indirectly, all administrative
departments, agencies, officers and employees appointed as provided immediately
above;
(3) Prepare a budget annually and submit it to the commission, be responsible
for the administration of the budget after it goes into effect, and recommend
to the commission any changes in the budget which the city manager deems
desirable;
(4) Submit to the commission a report as of the end of the fiscal year on the
finances and administrative activities of the city for the preceding year;
(5) Keep the commission advised of the financial condition and future needs of
the city, and make such recommendations on matters of policy and other matters
to the commission as may seem to the city manager desirable;
(6) To see that all laws and ordinances governing the city of Perkins are
enforced;
(7) To exercise actual management, control and supervision of and over all
departments of the city government, and to exercise all other administrative
functions, except as otherwise in this charter provided;
(8) To supervise and manage all public work of the city and the repair and
maintenance thereof, to manage and control the public utilities of the city,
and have general charge of the cleaning, lighting, and improving of the
streets, parks, sidewalks, bridges, and public grounds within and without the
city, except as otherwise herein provided;
(9) To make a monthly report to the commission and to attend all meetings of
the commission with the right to take part in the discussions but having no
vote;
(10) To see that all franchise rights and provisions are justly enforced;
(11) To submit to the mayor and commission at each meeting thereof an order of
business covering recommendations of the city manager;
(12) To create such departments for the more efficient and economical
administration of the affairs of the city as the city manager shall deem
necessary and expedient, subject to the approval of the commission;
(13) To have power at any time to investigate the affairs of any department and
make recommendations to the commission;
(14) Have such other powers, duties and functions as this charter may
prescribe, and such powers, duties and functions consistent with this charter
as the commission may prescribe.
Section 3-4. Administrative Departments, Offices And Agencies
There shall be such administrative departments, offices and agencies as this
charter establishes and as the commission may establish by ordinance. Each
administrative department shall be headed by a director with appropriate title
appointed by the city manager subject to approval of the city commission except
in case of the city attorney, or by a board whose members are appointed by the
city manager, as this charter or the commission by ordinance may determine.
Section 3-5. Department Of Finance: Directors: Duties
There shall be a director of finance, who shall be an officer of the city
appointed by the city manager for an indefinite term with approval of the
commission, and who shall be director, or head, of the department of finance;
provided, that the city manager may remove or suspend the director of finance
without approval of the commission. Subject to such regulations as the
commission may prescribe, the director of finance, with assistance of other
personnel in the department, shall collect or receive revenue and other money
for the city; shall be responsible for its custody, safekeeping, deposit,
investment, and disbursement, in accordance with this charter and the
ordinances of the city; and shall maintain a general accounting system for the
city government; provided that the commission by ordinance may transfer any of
said duties to other personnel in the department.
Section 3-6. City Attorney
There shall be a city attorney, who shall be an officer of the city appointed
by the commission for an indefinite term, and who shall be director, or head,
of the department of law. The commission shall appoint all other personnel in
the department unless it delegates the power to appoint designated personnel to
the city attorney. The city attorney shall, on request, advise the commission,
the city manager, and all other officers and agencies of the city government
regarding their legal powers, duties and functions, and draft or assist in
drafting legal documents. The city attorney or an attorney in the department
shall represent the city as attorney in all civil and criminal proceedings in
which the city is interested unless the commission secures special counsel for
particular proceedings.
Section 3-7. Municipal Judge
There shall be a municipal judge, who shall be appointed by the commission for
an indefinite term and who shall preside as the head of the municipal court
system.
ARTICLE IV. FISCAL AFFAIRS
Section 4-1. Purchases
(a) The city manager, subject to any regulations which the commission may
prescribe, shall contract for and purchase, or issue purchase authorizations
for, all supplies, materials, and equipment for the offices, departments and
agencies of the city government. Every such contract or purchase exceeding an
amount to be established by ordinance, shall require the prior approval of the
commission. The city manager also may transfer to or between offices,
departments, and agencies, surplus or obsolete supplies, materials, and
equipment, subject to such regulations as the commission may prescribe.
(b) The city manager may transfer some or all of the powers granted to the city
manager under this section to an officer or employee appointed by and
subordinate to the city manager, and may revoke any such transfer of powers.
Section 4-2. Contract For Public Improvement
All contracts pertaining to public improvements, maintenance of public
property, and public purchase of supplies, involving an outlay of as much as
$12,500.00 or such number as may be enacted and authorized by the state of
Oklahoma pursuant to the provisions of title 61, OS section 1 et seq., shall be
made by the board of commissioners and shall be based upon the specifications
provided by said board. All such contracts shall be let and awarded to the
lowest and best value bidder, by free and open competitive bidding after
solicitation for sealed bids, and no work shall be commenced until a written
contract is executed. Such contract shall be entered into only after
advertisement in a newspaper of general circulation in said city of Perkins on
the same day for two (2) consecutive weeks, that the first publication thereof
to be at least twenty (20) days prior to the date set for opening of bids. Such
competitive bid shall be sealed and one (1) copy of each bid shall be filed
with the city clerk; each bidder shall accompany his bid with a sworn statement
in writing that the bidder has not directly or indirectly entered into any
agreement expressed or implied with any other bidder or bidders having for its
object the control of the price and amount of such bid or bids, or limiting of
the bids or bidders or other person of any part of the contract or any part of
the subject matter of the bid, or the parts thereof. No bidder shall divulge
said sealed bid to any person whatever, except those having partnership or
other financial interests with such bidder in said bid until after said sealed
bids are opened. The violation of any of the foregoing provisions on the part
of the bidder shall make void any contract made by such bidder with said city
based upon said bid. The awarding of a contract upon a successful bid shall
give the bidder no right of action or claim against the city upon such contract
until the same shall have been reduced to writing and duly signed by the
contracting parties. All bids filed with the city clerk shall be opened in the
presence of the board of commissioners, and any bid received by the city clerk
more than ninety six (96) hours, excluding Saturdays, Sundays and holidays
before the time set for the opening of bids, or any bids so received after the
time set for opening of bids, shall not be considered by the board of
commissioners and shall be returned unopened to the bidder submitting same. The
board of commissioners shall consider said bids and may reject all bids and
readvertise for bids, or may enter into a contract with the party offering the
lowest responsible bid, or may have such work done under the supervision of the
proper department and keep account of the expenses thereof.
Provided that the Perkins city commission, by ordinance, may authorize and
create a bidding preference for those bidders located within the corporate
limits of the city of Perkins.
Pending advertisement or bids, the plans and specifications and profiles shall
remain on file in the office of the city clerk subject to inspection of any
person for the safeguarding of the interests of the city. The board of
commissioners shall make such regulations providing for the filing of the
estimate of the cost furnished them by the city engineer or anyone acting as
such engineer as they deem best. The board of commissioners shall have power to
require all bidders to make bonds or cash deposits as they may deem proper to
secure the performance of the contract, and to secure and guarantee the payment
of all claims for material and labor used and employed in the completion of the
work provided to be done in said contract.
Section 4-3. Surplus And Obsolete Property
When property of the city becomes obsolete or surplus, and no longer needed by
said city, the city commission shall determine the value thereof, before the
same is offered for sale. If the city commission determines that such property
to be offered for sale is surplus, obsolete and no longer needed then and in
that event the city commission may direct and authorize the city manager to
dispose of such surplus or obsolete property pursuant to Oklahoma Statutes.
Section 4-4. Sale Of Property
The sale or lease of the city property, real or personal, or the sale or other
disposal of any interest therein the value of which property, lease, or
interest is greater than an amount equal to five percent (5%) of the city of
Perkins general fund budget for the most immediate prior fiscal year budget or
the amount of $75,000.00 whichever amount is smaller shall be made only:
(1) By authority of an ordinance approved or enacted at an election by an
affirmative vote of a majority of the qualified voters of the city who vote on
the question of approving or enacting the ordinance (the ordinance being
submitted to the voters by the commission or by initiative of the voters); or
(2) By authority of a nonemergency ordinance passed by the commission, which
shall be published in full in a newspaper authorized by law to publish legal
publications within ten (10) days after its passage, and which shall include a
section reading substantially as follows:
"Section           . If one or more petitions with signatures signed by a
number of residents of the City of Perkins equal to not less than five (5)
percent of the City's total population as determined by the most recent federal
decennial census are properly filed within thirty (30) days after passage and
publication of this ordinance, this ordinance shall not go into effect until
the petition or petitions are finally found to be illegal and/or insufficient,
or, if any such petition is found legal and sufficient, until the ordinance is
approved at an election by a majority of the qualified voters voting on the
question. If no petition with signatures is filed, this ordinance shall go into
effect thirty (30) days after its passage and publication."
Section 4-5. Purchase Of Property
The purchase of any property, real or personal, or the acquisition of any
interest therein the value of which property, lease, or interest is greater
than an amount equal to four percent (4%) of the city of Perkins general fund
budget for the most immediate prior fiscal year budget or the amount of
$65,000.00 whichever amount is smaller shall be made only:
(1) By authority of an ordinance approved or enacted at an election by an
affirmative vote of a majority of the qualified voters of the city who vote on
the question of approving or enacting the ordinance (the ordinance being
submitted to the voters by the commission or by initiative of the voters); or
(2) By authority of a nonemergency ordinance passed by the commission, which
shall be published in full in a newspaper authorized by law to publish legal
publications within ten (10) days after its passage, and which shall include a
section reading substantially as follows:
"Section           . If one or more petitions with signatures signed by a
number of residents of the City of Perkins equal to not less than five (5)
percent of the City's total population as determined by the most recent federal
decennial census are properly filed within thirty (30) days after passage and
publication of this ordinance, this ordinance shall not go into effect until
the petition or petitions are finally found to be illegal and/or insufficient,
or, if any such petition is found legal and sufficient, until the ordinance is
approved at an election by a majority of the qualified voters voting on the
question. If no petition with signatures is filed, this ordinance shall go into
effect thirty (30) days after its passage and publication."
Section 4-6. Approval Of Claims
Every officer who shall approve, allow or pay any demand on the city of Perkins
not authorized by law, ordinance or this charter shall be liable to the city
individually and on such officer's official bond for the amount so illegally
approved, allowed or paid.
Section 4-7. Claims
Except as otherwise provided by the statutes of the state of Oklahoma, the
commission shall by ordinance provide the process for the approval for payment
and processing of claims and warrants against the city of Perkins.
Section 4-8. Capital Improvements Enacted By Voters
The voters of the city of Perkins shall have the power to authorize the city to
levy and collect a separate annual tax for capital improvement purposes on all
real, mixed and personal property in the city, not exempt from taxation by the
constitution and laws of the state of Oklahoma; provided, that for the purpose
of creating a capital improvement fund, such fund is to be used exclusively for
capital improvements within the city of Perkins. No such capital improvement
tax shall be imposed until such time as the question of imposing a capital
improvement tax shall have been submitted by the city to a vote by the voters
of the city of Perkins and the majority of the qualified voters of such city
voting at such election shall vote therefor. Provided that such question to be
voted on shall state that such tax shall be in an amount of mills on the dollar
of the assessed valuation of the taxable property in the city as approved by
the voters of the city of Perkins and that such tax shall not be in any larger
amount until again voted upon. Further that any such capital improvement tax as
authorized by a majority vote of the voters shall be for a maximum term of ten
(10) years. Upon the expiration of any capital improvement tax as authorized by
the voters no vote on any new, continued or additional capital improvement tax
shall occur until after a period of two (2) years. Any capital improvement tax
authorized under this section shall be in addition to and not a replacement for
any sales tax or other revenue producing measure intended for use to satisfy
any other indebtedness, obligation or bond of the city of Perkins and is not
intended to prohibit the enactment of any other indebtedness, obligation or
bond that might otherwise be allowed by statute or the constitution of the
state of Oklahoma.
Section 4-9. Ad Valorem Taxation
(1) The assessment of property of whatsoever kind in the city of Perkins, for
the purpose of levying thereon an ad valorem tax for the city of Perkins,
Oklahoma, shall be made by such officer and in all respects in the same manner
as is provided by the constitution and laws of the state of Oklahoma, or may
hereafter be provided by the constitution and laws of the said state, for the
assessment of property in cities of the first class for ad valorem taxation
purposes, and all property not rendered shall be assessed in the same manner as
is or may hereafter be provided in the laws of the state applicable to cities
of the first class.
(2) The ad valorem taxes for the city of Perkins shall hereafter be levied in
the same manner and by the same persons or officers as is provided by the
constitution or laws of the state of Oklahoma, or as may hereafter be provided
by the laws of the state of Oklahoma, applicable to cities of the first class,
unless provision shall exist in such laws with special reference to cities
having a charter form of government, in which case such levy shall be made in
the manner provided by such laws.
Section 4-10. Public Indebtedness
In pursuance of the statutes and constitution of the state of Oklahoma, the
powers of the city of Perkins, insofar as they pertain to the incurring of any
public indebtedness by the city of Perkins, and the manner of incurring such
indebtedness shall be in conformity with the constitution and general laws of
the state of Oklahoma relating thereto.
Section 4-11. Independent Annual Audit
The commission shall designate a qualified certified public accountant or
accountants who shall make an independent audit of the accounts and evidences
of financial transactions of the department of finance and of all other
departments of the city of Perkins, the Perkins public works authority, the
Perkins industrial development authority, and any other subordinate or related
entities and all other offices and agencies keeping separate or subordinate
accounts or making financial transactions as of the end of every fiscal year at
least, and who shall report to the commission and to the city manager. In lieu
of the above, the commission may arrange with an appropriate state authority
for such an audit when and if permitted by law.
Section 4-12. Budgets
The commission, the governing board of the Perkins public works authority, the
governing board of the Perkins industrial development authority and the
governing board of any other subordinate or related entity to the city of
Perkins shall prepare annually a fiscal year budget and approve same as the
annual operating budget for such commission or board.
Section 4-13. Compensation
The compensation of all appointive officers and employees shall be fixed and no
compensation shall be paid to any such officer or employee, except for the
salary or compensation pertaining to such office or position.
Section 4-14. Contracts
No contract shall be entered into by the city commission in excess of the
amount appropriated, and no contract shall be binding upon the city unless it
has been signed by the mayor or acting mayor, and attested by the city clerk
and the expense thereof encumbered in the proper fund liable for the payment of
the same, and whenever the contracts encumbered in any fund equal the
appropriation made therefor, no further contract shall be signed by the mayor
or attested by the city clerk for payment from such fund.
Section 4-15. Conflict Of Interest
(1) No officer or employee of said city shall give or promise to give to any
other person, any portion of such officer's compensation or any money or
valuable thing or promise of employment to any person in consideration of
having been or being nominated, appointed, voted for or elected to any office
or employment, and if such promise or gift be made, the person making or
accepting such gifts or promise shall forfeit office or employment and be
debarred and disqualified from being elected, appointed, or employed in the
service of said city.
(2) Any officer of said city who shall, while in office, accept any donation or
gratuity in money or other valuable thing, either directly or indirectly from
any person or corporation, or any subordinate or employee or from any candidate
or applicant for any position as employee or subordinate under such officer
shall forfeit office and be forever debarred and disqualified from holding any
position in the service of the city.
(3) Neither the mayor or any member of the city commission nor appointed
employee of the city, shall be directly or indirectly in the employ of any
person, company or corporation holding or seeking to hold any franchise of the
city or shall receive directly or indirectly any wages, commission, gifts, or
favor or payment from any such franchise holder; and any violation of this
section shall render vacant, ipso facto, the position held by the person so
violating it, and said person shall be punished as for bribery.
(4) Except as otherwise provided in this section the commission shall not make
any contract with any of its members or with any employee of the city or with
any company, individual or business concern in which any of its members or
employees of the city shall be directly or indirectly interested. All contracts
made in violation of this section shall be wholly void. A member of the
commission shall be considered to be interested in any contract made with any
company, individual, or any business concern if the member of the commission or
any member of the immediate family of the member owns any substantial interest
in same.
(5) It shall be unlawful for any candidate for office or for any officer or
employee of the city, directly or indirectly, to give or promise to give to any
person or persons, any office, position, employment, or anything of value, for
the purpose of influencing or obtaining support, political or otherwise, aid,
or influence of any person or persons; the doing of any such things shall be
grounds for removal from office of such officer, employee or candidate, if
elected.
(6) The mayor, each other commissioner and the city manager shall, within
thirty (30) days after taking office, file with the city clerk a statement of
economic interest as provided for herein. Such statement shall be kept current
and up-to-date at all times the person holds office.
The statement of economic interest required herein shall be on a form
prescribed by the city commission and contain the identity of all offices and
directorships held and a list of business or firms in which the commissioner or
city manager owns ten (10) percent or more interest and that do business with
or are regulated by the city of Perkins. In addition the commissioner or city
manager shall divulge at the time of consideration any real estate interest
within one thousand (1,000) feet of any property consideration that may come
before the city commission of the city of Perkins, Oklahoma.
Section 4-16. Nepotism
(1) Neither the city manager, the commission, nor any other authority of the
city government, may appoint or elect any person related to the mayor or any
other commissioner, to the city manager, or to such officer or commissioner, or
in the case of a plural authority, to one of its members, by affinity or
consanguinity within the second degree, to any office or position of profit in
the city government; but this shall not prohibit an officer or employee already
in the service of the city from continuing therein.
(2) Except as may be otherwise provided by this charter or by ordinance, the
same person may hold more than one office in the city government. The city
manager may hold more than one such office, through appointment by the city
manager, by the commission, or by other city authority having power to fill the
particular office, subject to any regulations which commission may make by
ordinance; but such person may not receive compensation for service in such
other offices. Also the commission by ordinance may provide that the city
manager shall hold ex officio designated offices subordinate to the city
manager as well as other designated compatible city offices, notwithstanding
any other provision of this charter.
ARTICLE V. ELECTIONS
Section 5-1. General Election Dates
A general election shall be held every year. The commissioners elected
hereafter shall be numbered one (1), two (2), three (3), and four (4).
In 2001 and every third year thereafter, a mayor shall be elected for a term of
three (3) years. After the initial election in 2001 referred to herein, in 2002
and every third year thereafter, commissioner no. 2 and commissioner no. 4
shall be elected for a term of three (3) years. After the initial election in
2001 referred to herein, in 2003 and every third year thereafter, commissioner
no. 1 and commissioner no. 3 shall be elected for terms of three (3) years.
The terms of the mayor and other commissioners shall begin at 7:30 o'clock P.M.
on the first Monday following their election and certification. If a mayor-
elect or a commissioner-elect fails to qualify within one month after the
beginning of such term, the election shall be void.
The mayor and other commissioners shall serve for the terms for which they are
elected and until successors are elected and qualify.
Section 5-2. Filing
Any qualified person as defined by this charter may have such person's name
placed on the ballot for the general election as a candidate for mayor or
commissioner by filing, with the secretary of the Payne County election board,
a sworn statement of candidacy for the particular office for which such person
is a candidate. Such statement of candidacy may be filed with the secretary of
the county election board no earlier than 8:00 A.M. on the first Monday in
February annually and no later than 5:00 P.M. on the next succeeding Wednesday.
Any candidate may contest the candidacy of any other candidate for the same
office by filing a written petition with the secretary of the county election
board with whom said candidate filed the statement of candidacy. In the event
only one candidate files for an office, a petition contesting such candidacy
may be filed by any registered voter. Said petition must be filed no later than
5:00 P.M. on the second day following the closing of the filing period.
Section 5-3. Election Procedures
A general election shall be held on the date established by the general
elections laws of the state of Oklahoma, or in the absence of such legislation,
by ordinance, every year to elect a mayor or commissioners to succeed the mayor
or commissioners whose terms are expiring, as the case may be. Every qualified
elector of the city shall be entitled to vote for one candidate for each office
to be filled. The instruction "vote for one" shall be placed between the title
of the office and the names of the candidates. The candidate for an office
receiving the greater number of votes shall be elected. In case of failure to
elect because of a tie, the election shall be determined fairly by lot in a
meeting of the county election board and under its direction, from among the
candidates tying.
Section 5-4. Nonpartisan
Municipal elections shall be nonpartisan and all candidates shall file as
independent candidates. No primary elections shall be held in a nonpartisan
election.
Section 5-5. Vacancy
When a mayor, commissioner or commissioners are being elected to fill a vacancy
or vacancies for the rest of the unexpired terms, the provisions of this
article shall apply as in the election of mayor and commissioners for regular
terms, insofar as they are applicable. The phrase "for unexpired term" shall be
placed after the title of an office on the ballot in such a case, for the
information of the electors.
Section 5-6. Unopposed Candidacy
If there is only one candidate for a particular office, the candidate shall be
not only nominated, but also elected ipso facto; and his name shall not appear
on the ballots for the general election. If there is only one candidate for
each of the offices which are to be filled at the election, and no questions
are to be voted upon at the election, the general municipal election shall not
be held.
Section 5-7. Voting Qualifications
Only voters residing in this city who have the qualifications prescribed for
voters by the state constitution and law, and who are registered as may be
required by law, may vote in city elections.
Section 5-8. State Election Provisions
The provisions of the state constitution and law applicable to city elections,
shall govern such elections in this city insofar as they are applicable and are
not superseded by this charter or by ordinance.
A proclamation of the mayor calling a special election shall give the locations
of polling places.
Section 5-9. Absentee Ballots
Absentee ballots may be provided for in elections conducted under the
provisions of this charter. Provided, however, this section shall not prohibit
the board of commissioners by ordinance from establishing conditions for the
use of absentee ballots in the municipal elections held under these provisions.
ARTICLE VI. MUNICIPAL COURT
Section 6-1. Judicial Department: Municipal Court Created
The judicial power of the city of Perkins shall be vested in the municipal
court created by this charter. The municipal judge shall be judge of the
municipal court and all trials and proceedings in said court shall be heard and
determined by the municipal judge, which court shall have and possess the
jurisdiction and powers possessed by municipal courts under the statutes of the
state of Oklahoma.
Section 6-2. Municipal Judge
Such court shall be presided over by a judge, to be known as the municipal
judge, whose appointment shall be made, duties defined, and compensation fixed
by the board of commissioners.
Section 6-3. Municipal Court
The municipal court shall have original jurisdiction to hear and determine all
prosecutions wherein a violation of any ordinance of the municipality where the
court is established is charged. The municipal judge shall keep a record of all
proceedings of the municipal court, of the disposition of all cases, and of all
fines and other money collected. The municipal judge may issue warrants and
subpoenas, administer oaths and affirmations, make and enforce all proper
orders, rules and judgments, and punish for contempt.
Section 6-4. Appeals From Municipal Court
An appeal may be taken from a final judgment of the municipal court by the
defendant by filing in the district court of Payne County within ten (10) days
from the date of the final judgment a notice of appeal and by filing a copy of
the notice with the municipal court. No such appeal shall be allowed unless the
defendant shall enter into a recognizance with good and sufficient sureties to
be approved by the municipal judge, conditioned for the personal appearance of
the appellant before the district court of the Payne County, in the amount of
the judgment and costs; provided that in no case shall the bond be less than
$50.00.
Section 6-5. Fines Paid To The City Clerk Of The City Of Perkins
All fines, penalties, forfeitures and collections made by said municipal court
shall be the property of the city and shall be immediately deposited with the
city clerk for the use of the city.
Section 6-6. Municipal Court Rules And Regulations
The board of commissioners may provide by ordinance all rules and regulations
necessary for the prompt and efficient conduct of the business of said
municipal court, not inconsistent with this charter.
Section 6-7. Forfeit Of Bonds
In all cases of breach of any bonds, or recognizance entered into before the
municipal court same shall be declared forfeited by the judge of the municipal
court and the city attorney shall cause the same to be prosecuted against the
principal and sureties, or the sureties alone.
Section 6-8. Fines May Be Remitted
The board of commissioners shall have power on recommendation of the municipal
judge to remit fines and grant pardons after convictions in the municipal court
of the city of Perkins.
ARTICLE VII. ORDINANCES
Section 7-1. Ordinances: Enacting Clause
The style of all ordinances shall be, "BE IT ORDAINED BY THE CITY COMMISSION OF
THE CITY OF PERKINS", but such caption may be omitted when said ordinances are
revised and digested under the order of the commission, or when they are
published in book form.
Section 7-2. Ordinances: Title
Every ordinance adopted by the commission shall embrace but one subject, which
shall be clearly expressed in its title. No repealed ordinance shall be
revived, amended, or the provisions thereof extended or conferred by reference
to title only; but so much thereof as is revived, amended, extended or
conferred shall be re-enacted and published at length; provided, that if any
subject be embraced in any ordinance contrary to the provisions of this
section, such ordinance shall be void only as to so much of the ordinance as
may not be expressed in the title thereof.
Section 7-3. Ordinances: Passage
Three members of the commission shall constitute a quorum, the mayor being
counted as a member, and the affirmative vote of at least three members shall
be necessary to adopt any motion or resolution or pass any ordinance, or other
measure.
Section 7-4. Ordinances: Effective Date
All ordinances passed by the commission, except emergency ordinances, shall
take effect and become valid at the end of thirty days (30) from the date of
passage of such ordinance unless such ordinance specifies at a later time. All
ordinances shall be published in full or by title in a newspaper meeting the
requirements of the statutes of the state of Oklahoma in respect to legal
publications, published and of general circulation within the city of Perkins,
such publication to be within ten days (10) from the passage of the ordinance.
Section 7-5. Emergency Ordinance
An emergency ordinance is an ordinance, which in the judgment of the
commission, is necessary for the immediate preservation of peace, health, or
safety, and which should become effective prior to the time an ordinary
ordinance would become effective. Every such ordinance shall contain, as a part
of its title, the words, "and declaring an emergency" and in a separate
section, herein called the emergency section, shall declare the emergency. The
commission shall vote on the emergency section separately. An affirmative vote
of at least four (4) commissioners shall be required for passage of an
emergency ordinance, which vote shall be by yeas and nays, and shall be entered
in the journal. An emergency ordinance shall take effect upon passage and
publication unless it specifies at a later time.
Section 7-6. Ordinances: Adoption By Reference
The commission by ordinance may adopt by reference codes, ordinances, standards
and regulations relating to buildings, plumbing, electrical installations and
other matters which it has power to regulate otherwise. Such code, ordinance,
standard or regulations so adopted need not be enrolled in the book of
ordinances, but a copy shall be filed and kept in the office of the city clerk.
The city clerk shall keep copies of all such codes, ordinances, standards and
regulations in force for distribution or sale at their approximate cost.
Section 7-7. Ordinances: Codification
The ordinances of the city shall be codified and published in book or pamphlet
form at least every ten years (10) unless the commission, by use of a looseleaf
system and process of amendment, keeps the code up to date. Titles, enacting
clauses, and emergency sections may be omitted from the code, and temporary and
special ordinances and parts of ordinances may be omitted. Permanent general
ordinances and parts of ordinances which are to be repealed by the code shall
be omitted from the code. The ordinances and parts of ordinances included in
the code may be revised, rearranged and reorganized; and the code may contain
new matter, provisions of the state constitution and law relating to the city
of Perkins and provisions of this charter. A copy of the published code shall
be filed in the office of the city clerk after adoption by the commission, but
the code need not be enrolled in the book of ordinances.
Section 7-8. Ordinances Admitted As Evidence
All printed ordinances or codes of ordinances published by authority of the
commission, shall, in all judicial proceedings, in all courts, be admitted in
evidence, and in such proceedings it shall not be necessary to plead the entire
ordinances or section, but only such parts thereof as are offered in evidence.
ARTICLE VIII. MISCELLANEOUS
Section 8-1. Charter Amendments By Commission
An amendment or amendments to this charter, or a substitute for this charter
may be proposed by the board of commissioners and such proposed amendment or
amendments or such substitute charter shall, with yeas and nays thereon be
entered in the journal, and referred by the Payne County election board to the
people of the city of Perkins for their approval or rejection, at the next
regular general election, except when the board of commissioners by a unanimous
vote order a special election for the purpose. If a majority of all the
electors voting at such election shall vote in favor of any amendments thereto,
it shall be submitted to the governor of the state of Oklahoma and on approval
one (1) copy thereof shall be deposited in the office of the secretary of
state, and the other after being recorded in the office of the county clerk of
Payne County, shall be deposited in the archives of the city, and said
amendment shall become a part of this charter. If a majority of all of the
electors voting in any such election shall vote in favor of a substitute for
this charter, it shall be submitted to the governor of the state of Oklahoma,
and on approval a copy thereof shall be deposited in the office of the
secretary of state, and another copy after being recorded in the office of the
county clerk of Payne County shall be deposited in the archives of the city.
Said substitute charter shall then supersede this charter and become the
organic law of the city of Perkins. If two or more amendments are proposed,
they shall be submitted in such manner that the electors may vote for them or
against them separately; provided that this section shall not impair the right
of the people to amend this charter by a vote upon an initiative petition
therefore.
Section 8-2. Charter Amendment By Petition
Any amendment to this charter or substitute for this charter may be submitted
to the board of commissioners by a petition signed by a number of residents of
Perkins equal to twenty percent (20%) of the number of votes cast in the most
recent city of Perkins general municipal election. All petitions circulated
with respect to any proposed amendment or proposed substitute charter shall be
uniform in character, shall contain the proposed amendment or substitute
charter in full, and shall have printed or written thereon the names and
addresses of at least five (5) electors, who shall be officially regarded as
filing the petition, and shall constitute a committee of the petitioners for
the purposes hereinafter mentioned. Each signer of the petition shall sign such
person's name in ink, and shall place on the petition opposite such person's
name and the date of the signature, and such person's place of residence by
voting precinct and by street number; provided that if there be no street
number such person may give the number of the lot and block on which the house
in which such person lives is located. The signatures on any such petition need
not all be appended to one paper, but on each paper there shall be attached an
affidavit by the circulator thereof stating the number of signatures to such
part of the petition, and that each signature appended to the paper is the
genuine signature of the person whose name it purports to be and that it was
made in the presence of the affiant, and on the date indicated. All papers
comprising the petition shall be assembled and filed with the city clerk as one
instrument, within sixty (60) days from the date of the first signature
thereon, and when so filed with the city clerk shall submit the same to the
board of commissioners at its next regular meeting. When said petition has been
filed, signed by twenty percent (20%) of the qualified voters of the city of
Perkins, as determined by the highest number of votes cast at the next
preceding general municipal election, it shall be the duty of the board of
commissioners through its chairman to call a special election within thirty
(30) days from the date of their first meeting after the filing of said
petition with the city clerk for the purpose of submitting to the voters of the
city of Perkins for their ratification the proposed amendment, or the proposed
substitute charter. If the majority of the voters at such election vote in
favor of adopting such amendment or amendments, or substitute charter, the same
shall be submitted to the governor of the state of Oklahoma and on approval, a
copy thereof shall be filed in the office of the county clerk of Payne County,
shall be deposited in the archives of the city, and the same shall immediately
become effective as an amendment or amendments to this charter, or a substitute
for this charter.
Section 8-3. Initiative And Referendum
In pursuance of the constitution of the state of Oklahoma, the powers of
initiative and referendum are reserved to the qualified electors in the city of
Perkins, insofar as they may affect legislation enacted by the city commission,
and the manner of exercising such rights shall be in conformity with the
constitution and general laws of the state of Oklahoma relating thereto.
Section 8-4. Municipal Powers
The city of Perkins shall have all other powers that may thereafter be given it
by the constitution and the laws of this state, and where any provision of this
charter shall be in conflict with any laws relating to cities of the first
class in force at the time of the adoption and approval of this charter, the
provisions of this charter shall operate as a repeal or suspension of such
state law or laws to the extent of such conflict, and said city shall have the
power to enact and enforce all ordinances necessary to protect the health, life
and property and to prevent and summarily abate and remove nuisances and
preserve and enforce good government and order for the security of the city and
its inhabitants, to protect the lives, health and property of the city, and to
enact and enforce all ordinances upon any subject; provided, that no ordinance
shall be enacted inconsistent with the constitution and general laws of the
state or with this charter.
Section 8-5. Bonds Of Officers And Employees
The officers and employees of the city of Perkins as may be required by the
board of commissioners shall execute such bond as the board of commissioners
may by ordinance require; the cost of such bonds to be paid by the city. The
board of commissioners shall also provide for the proper recording of the said
bonds when they are accepted and approved.
Section 8-6. Reservation Of Control Over Public Highways
No grant, extension or renewal of any franchise or other use of the streets,
alleys or other public grounds of this municipality, shall divest the city of
its control and regulation of such use and enjoyment. Nor shall the power to
regulate the charges for public services be surrendered and no exclusive
franchise shall ever be granted.
Section 8-7. Commission To Frame Law
The commission shall be vested with the power of adopting all laws and
ordinances not inconsistent with the constitution and laws of this state for
the taxation, regulation, and control of all public service and public utility
corporations now or hereafter existing or operating in whole or in part within
the city.
Section 8-8. Power Of Taxation Over Public Service Corporations
All grants and renewals of franchises and privileges shall reserve to the city
the right to terminate the same and to purchase all the property of the utility
in the streets, avenues, alleys and public places in the city and elsewhere as
may be provided in the franchise making the grant or renewal, used in or useful
for the operation of the utility, at such prices as may be agreed upon between
the owner and the city; and in the event of disagreement the same may at the
option of the city be submitted to arbitration under the arbitration laws of
the state of Oklahoma; or in the event no arbitration agreement can be reached,
then the city may obtain such property by condemnation under the eminent domain
laws of the state of Oklahoma.
Section 8-9. Purchase Price
No franchise making such grant or renewal shall be valid unless it shall
expressly provide therein that the price to be paid by the city for the
property that may be acquired by it from such utility, by purchase,
