therefore that he was properly served therewith. (2010 Code § 14-37)
E.   Jury To Sit Together: After jurors are sworn, they shall sit together and
hear the proof and oral arguments of the parties, which must be delivered in
public and in the presence of the defendant. (2010 Code § 14-38)
F.   Judge To Determine Questions Of Law: In all actions tried before a jury,
the judge shall determine all questions of law, including questions as to the
introduction of evidence, arising during the trial. He also shall instruct the
jury as to the law. (2010 Code § 14-39)
G.   Vote Required For Verdict: A verdict of the jury may be rendered by the
vote of five (5) jurors. (2010 Code § 14-40)
H.   Verdict Of Jury Generally:
   1.   The verdict of the jury, in all cases, must be general. When the jury
has arrived at its verdict, it must deliver the verdict publicly to the court.
The judge must enter the verdict in the docket, or cause it to be so entered.
   2.   The jury must not be discharged after the cause is submitted to it
until a verdict is rendered, unless the judge, for good cause, discharges it
sooner, in which event the court may proceed again to trial, and so on, until a
verdict is rendered. (2010 Code § 14-41)
I.   Misconduct Of Jurors; Influencing Jurors:
   1.   No juror or person drawn or summoned as a juror in the court shall
either make any promise or agreement to give a verdict for or against the city,
permit any communication to be made to him, or to receive any book, paper,
instruments or information relative to any cause pending before him, except in
the regular course of proceedings and the trial of the case.
   2.   No juror summoned by the court shall ask, receive or agree to receive,
any bribe upon any understanding concerning his vote or decision upon any case
in which he may be selected as a juror in the court.
   3.   No person shall attempt to influence a juror summoned to appear in the
court, or any person summoned as a juror, in respect to his verdict, either by
means of communication, oral or written, had by him, except in the regular
course of proceedings; by means of any books, paper or instruments, exhibited
otherwise than in the regular course of proceedings, by any means of threat or
intimidation; by means of any assurance, promise of any pecuniary or other
advantage; by publishing any statement, argument or observation relating to the
case; or by talking with such juror concerning the case in any way. (2010 Code
§ 14-42)
J.   Responsibility Of Officer In Charge Of Jury: No officer to whose charge
any jury is committed by the municipal court shall neglect or wilfully permit
such juror, or any of them, either to receive any communication from any
person; to make any communication to any person; to obtain or to receive any
book, paper or refreshment; or to leave the jury room without leave of the
court being first obtained. (2010 Code § 14-43)
K.   Compensation Of Jurors: Jurors shall receive for their services the sum of
twelve dollars fifty cents ($12.50) per day, plus mileage at the rate of ten
cents ($0.10) per mile for each mile necessarily traveled by the most direct
route in going to and from the court from their respective places of residence.
The claims for such compensation shall show the location of the juror's
residence and the route and miles traveled and must be verified as other claims
against the municipality are verified. Jurors shall be paid out of the general
funds of the city. (2010 Code § 14-44)
1-8-25: FEES AND COURT COSTS:
A.   Fees:
   1.   The municipal court clerk, chief of police or the chief of police
designee is authorized to charge and collect fees for the following, such
amounts to be as established by resolution of the city commission:
      a.   For preparing and furnishing, upon request, a copy of a motor
vehicle accident report on file in the traffic division of the police
department;
      b.   For preparing and furnishing, upon request, a copy of the record of
arrest, commonly known as transcript, for the violation of statutes and/or
ordinances;
      c.   For searching, upon request, the records on file in the police
department;
      d.   For certifying the authenticity of any document copied.
   2.   The fees set out in this subsection shall not be charged or collected
for any such services rendered for or upon request of an agent or officer of
the federal, state, county, city or other governmental bodies.
B.   Court Costs: If judgment of conviction is entered, the municipal judge may
order the clerk of the court to tax court costs in the maximum amount of thirty
dollars ($30.00) to the defendant, plus any fees and mileage for witnesses, any
costs or fees mandated by the council on law enforcement training, any costs or
fees collected on behalf of the bureau of narcotics drug education revolving
fund, and any costs or fees collected on behalf of the Oklahoma state bureau of
investigation all in addition to any fine that might be imposed. (Ord. 445, 11-
8-2016)
CHAPTER 9
EMPLOYEE RETIREMENT
ARTICLE A. FEDERAL OLD AGE AND SURVIVORS INSURANCE
SECTION:
1-9A-1: Policy And Purpose
1-9A-2: Mayor Authorized To Execute Agreements
1-9A-3: Withholdings From Salaries And Wages
1-9A-4: Appropriations For Employer Contributions
1-9A-5: Records And Reports
1-9A-6: Employees And Officers Now Covered By Other Retirement Systems
1-9A-7: Excluded Employees And Officers
1-9A-1: POLICY AND PURPOSE:
It is hereby declared to be the policy and purpose of this city to extend at
the earliest date to the employee and officials thereof, not excluded by law or
ordinance, and whether employed in connection with a governmental or
proprietary function, the benefits of the system of federal social act, and
amendments thereto, including public law 734, 81st congress. In pursuance of
said policy, and for that purpose, the city shall take such actions as may be
required by applicable state or federal laws or regulations. (2010 Code § 1-70)
1-9A-2: MAYOR AUTHORIZED TO EXECUTE AGREEMENTS:
The mayor is hereby authorized and directed to execute all necessary agreements
and amendments thereto with the state department of public welfare, as agent or
agency, to secure coverage of employees and officials as provided in section
1-9A-1 of this article. (2010 Code § 1-71)
1-9A-3: WITHHOLDINGS FROM SALARIES AND WAGES:
Withholdings from salaries or wages of employees and officials for the purpose
provided in section
1-9A-1 of this article are hereby authorized to be made in the amounts and at
such times as may be required by applicable state or federal laws or
regulations, and be paid over to the state or federal agency designated by said
laws or regulations. (2010 Code § 1-72)
1-9A-4: APPROPRIATIONS FOR EMPLOYER CONTRIBUTIONS:
There shall be appropriated from available funds such amounts at such times as
may be required by applicable state or federal laws or regulations for employer
contributions; which shall be paid over to the state or federal agency
designated by said laws or regulations. (2010 Code § 1-73)
1-9A-5: RECORDS AND REPORTS:
This municipality shall keep such records and make such reports as may be
required by applicable state or federal laws or regulations. (2010 Code § 1-74)
1-9A-6: EMPLOYEES AND OFFICERS NOW COVERED BY OTHER RETIREMENT SYSTEMS:
There is hereby excluded from this article any authority to make any agreement
with respect to any position or any employee or official now covered or
authorized to be covered by any other ordinance creating any retirement system
for any employee or official of the municipality. (2010 Code § 1-75)
1-9A-7: EXCLUDED EMPLOYEES AND OFFICERS:
There is hereby excluded from this article any authority to make any agreement
with respect to any position, or any employee or official, compensation for
whom is on a fee basis, or any position, or any official not authorized to be
covered by applicable state or federal laws or regulations. (2010 Code § 1-76)
ARTICLE B. FIREMEN'S PENSION
SECTION:
1-9B-1: Board Of Trustees Of Firemen's Relief And Pension Fund Created
1-9B-2: Funds Operated According To Law
1-9B-1: BOARD OF TRUSTEES OF FIREMEN'S RELIEF AND PENSION FUND CREATED:
There is hereby created the board of trustees of the firemen's relief and
pension fund of this municipality, with membership, organization, and powers,
duties and functions as prescribed by 11 Oklahoma Statutes section 49-101 et
seq., and as may be provided by any later laws relating to said board. (2010
Code § 1-77)
1-9B-2: FUNDS OPERATED ACCORDING TO LAW:
The fireman's relief and pension fund shall be operated in accordance with
state law relating to the fund and pensions and other benefits shall be paid as
provided by state law. (2010 Code § 1-78)
ARTICLE C. EMPLOYEE RETIREMENT SYSTEM
SECTION:
1-9C-1: Created
1-9C-2: Administration
1-9C-3: Fund
1-9C-4: Appropriations
1-9C-5: Execution
1-9C-1: CREATED:
A.   Defined Contribution Plan: Pursuant to the authority conferred by the laws
of the state, and for the purpose of encouraging continuity and meritorious
service on the part of the city employees and thereby promoting public
efficiency, there is hereby authorized, created, established, approved and
adopted, effective as of April 1, 2022, the amended and restated plan
designated "Employee Retirement System of City of Perkins, Oklahoma, Defined
Contribution Plan", hereinafter called "Defined Contribution Plan," an executed
counterpart of which is marked Exhibit "A" (Joinder Agreement) and Exhibit "B"
(amended and restated plan) and is to be filed in the office of the city clerk
of said city.
B.   Defined Benefit Plan: Pursuant to the authority conferred by the laws of
the state, and for the purpose of encouraging continuity and meritorious
service on the part of City employees and thereby promote public efficiency,
there is hereby authorized created, established, and approved and adopted,
effective as of January 1, 2025, the amended and restated plan designated
"Employee Retirement System of the City of Perkins, Oklahoma, Defined Benefit
Plan", hereinafter called "Defined Benefit Plan," an executed counterpart of
which is marked Exhibit "A" (Joinder Agreement) and Exhibit "B" (amended and
restated plan) and is to be filed in the office of the city of clerk of said
city.
C.   System: The Defined Contribution Plan and the Defined Benefit Plan are
hereinafter referred to as "the system." (2010 Code § 1-79; amd. Ord. 482, 12-
10-2019; Ord. 488, 3-8-2022; Ord. 511, 12-10-2024)
1-9C-2: ADMINISTRATION:
For the purpose of administration of the system, there is hereby established a
retirement committee, which shall be the members of the city commission, as now
existing or as from time to time duly elected or appointed and constituted. The
powers and duties of the retirement committee shall be as set forth in the
system instrument filed in the office of the city clerk. (2010 Code § 1-80;
amd. Ord. 511, 12-10-2024)
1-9C-3: FUND:
A fund is hereby provided for the exclusive use and benefit of the persons
entitled to benefits under the system. All contributions to such funds shall be
paid over to and received in trust for such purpose by the city. Such funds
shall be pooled for purposes of management and investment with similar funds of
other incorporated cities, towns, and municipal trusts in the state as a part
of the Oklahoma Municipal Retirement Fund, in accordance with the trust
agreement of the Oklahoma Municipal Retirement Fund, a public trust. The city
shall hold such contributions in the form received, and from time to time pay
over and transfer the same to the Oklahoma Municipal Retirement Fund, as duly
authorized and directed by the Board of Trustees. The fund shall be nonfiscal
and shall not be considered in computing any levy when the annual estimate is
made to the County Excise Board. (2010 Code § 1-81; amd. Ord. 482, 12-10-2019;
Ord. 488, 3-8-2022; Ord. 511, 12-10-2024)
1-9C-4: APPROPRIATIONS:
The city is hereby authorized to incur the necessary expenses for the
establishment, operation and administration of the system and to appropriate
and pay the same. In addition, the city is hereby authorized to appropriate
annually such amounts as are required in addition to employee contributions, to
maintain the system and fund in accordance with the provisions of the Defined
Contribution Plan and/or the Defined Benefit Plan. Any appropriation so made to
maintain the system and fund shall be for deferred wages or salaries and for
the payment of necessary expenses of operation and administration, to be
transferred to the trustees of the Oklahoma Municipal Retirement Fund for such
purposes, and shall be paid into the fund when available, to be duly
transferred to the Oklahoma Municipal Retirement Fund. (2010 Code § 1-82; amd.
Ord. 482, 12-10-2019; Ord. 488, 3-8-2022; Ord. 511, 12-10-2024)
1-9C-5: EXECUTION:
A.   The Mayor and City Clerk be and they are each hereby authorized and
directed to execute (in counterparts, each of which shall constitute an
original) the system instrument, and to do all other acts and things necessary,
advisable and proper to put said system and related trust into full force and
effect, and to make such changes therein as may be necessary to qualify the
same under sections 401(a) and 501(a) of the Internal Revenue Code of the
United States.
B.   This Committee is hereby authorized and directed to proceed immediately on
behalf of the City of Perkins, Oklahoma, to pool and combine the Fund into the
Oklahoma Municipal Retirement Fund as a part thereof, with similar funds of
such other cities and towns, for purposes of pooled management and investment.
C.   Amendments: The Defined Contribution Plan and the Defined Benefit Plan may
be amended by approval of a resolution by the city commission. (2010 Code § 1-
83; amd. Ord. 482, 12-10-2019; Ord. 488, 3-8-2022; Ord. 511, 12-10-2024)
CHAPTER 10
OPEN PUBLIC RECORDS
SECTION:
1-10-1: Inspection And Copying Of Open Public Records
1-10-2: Inspection Of Open Public Records
1-10-3: Copies Of Open Public Records
1-10-4: Fees For Copying Records
1-10-1: INSPECTION AND COPYING OF OPEN PUBLIC RECORDS:
The following procedures are hereby adopted and shall be applied by each
official custodian and records custodian:
A.   Consistent with the policy, duties and procedures established by the
Oklahoma open records act, records custodians shall provide full access and
assistance in a timely and efficient manner to persons who request access to
open public records.
B.   Records custodians shall protect the integrity and organization of public
records with respect to the manner in which such records are inspected and
copied.
C.   Records custodians may prevent excessive disruptions of essential
functions and provide the record at the earliest possible time.
D.   All inspections and copying of open public records shall be performed by
or under the supervision of the records custodian for the city who is
responsible for such records.
E.   All persons requesting the inspection of or a copy of open public records
shall make such request in writing prior to the request being honored, except
that no form shall be required for requests made for records which have been
reproduced for free public distribution.
F.   All records inspection and copying forms are to be completed by the person
requesting the record. In all cases, the party so requesting must sign his or
her individual name to the inspection request ledger. The records custodian may
demand reasonable identification of any person requesting a record. Any written
requests shall be made on the form provided by the records custodian and
presented to the records custodian.
G.   Any fees for records inspection or for copies are due at the time the
records, or copies thereof, are provided to the requester, unless the records
custodian has demanded that prepayment of all or part of such fees be made.
Fees are to be paid to the records custodian.
H.   The records custodian for the city shall demand full or partial prepayment
of fees whenever his or her estimate for such fees exceed ten dollars ($10.00).
I.   No record search or copying charge shall be assessed against officers or
employees of the city who make requests which are reasonably necessary to the
performance of their official duties.
J.   Hours for making requests for inspection or copying shall be all regular
working hours for each day the office maintains regular office hours.
K.   Removal of open public records from the office where kept and maintained,
for purposes of inspection and/or the making of copies, shall not be permitted
by the city.
L.   The above procedures, as well as any other inspection and copying
procedures, shall be posted in a conspicuous place in the office of the records
custodian. (2010 Code § 1-66)
1-10-2: INSPECTION OF OPEN PUBLIC RECORDS:
The following procedures are hereby adopted and shall be applied by every
official custodian and records custodian within the city:
A.   Records custodians shall handle all inspection requests in accordance with
their duties to protect and preserve public records and to assist persons
requesting inspection of open public records.
B.   A written request is sufficient if it reasonably describes the record
sought. In instances where the requester cannot provide sufficient information
to identify a record, the custodian shall assist in making such identification.
C.   The records custodian shall, upon making a denial of an inspection
request, forward a copy of the denial to the city attorney that he has made an
inspection request denial. (2010 Code § 1-67)
1-10-3: COPIES OF OPEN PUBLIC RECORDS:
The following procedures are hereby adopted and shall be applied by each
official custodian and records custodian within the city:
A.   Records custodians shall handle all copy requests in accordance with their
duties to protect and preserve public records and to assist persons requesting
copies of open public records.
B.   Mechanical reproduction of a record shall not be undertaken when it is the
judgment of the records custodian that any available means of mechanically
reproducing the subject record is likely to cause damage to such record.
C.   No copy fee shall be assessed when multiple copies of the records
requested have been prepared for free public distribution, or when the records
custodian determines that the cost of charging and handling the fee exceeds the
cost of providing a copy without charge. (2010 Code § 1-68)
1-10-4: FEES FOR COPYING RECORDS:
There is hereby levied and assessed the following fees and costs for the
copying of records by the city: (2010 Code § 1-69)
A.   There shall be charged a document copying fee in such amount as
established by resolution of the city commission. (2010 Code § 1-69; amd. 2012
Code)
However, if the request:
   1.   Is solely for commercial purposes; or
   2.   Would clearly cause excessive disruption of the public body's essential
functions;
then there shall be charged an additional search fee, which fee shall be equal
to the lowest hourly secretarial salary paid by the city of Perkins at the time
of the request, times the number of hours spent by city employees in meeting
the request. For purposes hereof, the smallest sequence of time shall be one-
half (1/2) hour. It is the intent of the city commission the above fees are to
reimburse the city for its costs and expenses in providing the copying of open
public records.
B.   Publication in a newspaper or broadcast by news media for news purposes
shall not constitute a resale or use of data for trade or commercial purpose,
and charges for providing copies of electronic data to the news media for a
news purpose shall not exceed the direct cost of making the copy.
C.   A search fee shall not be added to the copying fee when the release of
said documents is in the public interest, including, but not limited to,
release to the news media, scholars, authors and taxpayers seeking to determine
whether those entrusted with the affairs of the government are honestly,
faithfully and competently performing their duties as public servants. (2010
Code § 1-69)
TITLE 2
REVENUE, FINANCE AND BUSINESS
CHAPTER 1
GENERAL PROVISIONS
SECTION:
2-1-1: Purchases And Sales
2-1-2: Rental Of Real Property Or Equipment
2-1-3: Agreements For Use Of City Owned Property
2-1-1: PURCHASES AND SALES:
All purchases of supplies, materials, equipment and contractual services for
the city, and any sales thereof by the city, shall be made by the city
commission, or pursuant to authorizations granted by it, and subject to its
supervision and control and subject to the provisions of this title. (2010 Code
§ 6-11)
2-1-2: RENTAL OF REAL PROPERTY OR EQUIPMENT:
The city is authorized to rent on a monthly basis real property or equipment,
and to pay the rental charges thereon, for usage during any fiscal period or
portion thereof, provided such payment be made out of appropriations made and
approved for such purpose for such fiscal year, it being the intention hereof
that the city comply with the provisions of 62 Oklahoma Statutes section 430.1.
(2010 Code § 6-11; amd. 2012 Code)
2-1-3: AGREEMENTS FOR USE OF CITY OWNED PROPERTY:
The city commission is authorized to enter into agreements for use of city
owned property; provided, that said use will benefit the general health, safety
and welfare; and further provided, that any such agreement shall be in
conformity with Oklahoma Statutes. (2010 Code § 6-11)
CHAPTER 2
PURCHASES OF SUPPLIES, MATERIALS AND EQUIPMENT
SECTION:
2-2-1: City Manager To Purchase; Prior Approval Required
2-2-2: Contacting Local Vendors, Exception; Lowest Bid
2-2-3: Contract For Public Improvements
2-2-1: CITY MANAGER TO PURCHASE; PRIOR APPROVAL REQUIRED:
   A.   Subject to the provisions of this section, the city manager, or some
other person or persons duly authorized by him, shall contract for professional
services and purchases or issue purchase authorization for all supplies,
materials and equipment for the offices, departments and agencies of the city
government; provided, that any single purchases for a price exceeding twenty-
five thousand dollars ($25,000.00) shall not be made until specifically
approved by the City Commission; provided, however, that this section shall not
apply to emergency services, acquisitions and contracts, including emergency
repairs of equipment and machinery. The City Manager shall specify in writing
the facts and circumstances giving rise to such emergency and shall provide
such written justification to the city prior to issuing or creating an
emergency expenditure, acquisition or contract, or as soon thereafter as
feasible.
   B.   The City Manager, or his duly authorized representative, is hereby
authorized and empowered, for purposes of subsection A of this section, to make
use of and to avail themselves of the provisions of the Oklahoma central
purchasing contracts and the services of its purchasing director; provided,
that any competitive bid requirements found hereunder shall not apply to
contracts or purchases made under and through the provisions of the Oklahoma
central purchasing contracts and the services of its purchasing director. (Ord.
435, 9-8-2015; amd. Ord. 493, 12-13-2022; Ord. 506, 9-10-2024)
2-2-2: CONTACTING LOCAL VENDORS, EXCEPTION; LOWEST BID:
Except in cases of emergency, the city manager, or his duly authorized
representative, shall contact by mail, phone or in person, local proprietors of
businesses operating in the city and vicinity who may be interested in
furnishing the supplies, materials and equipment needed by the city, and shall
use his best efforts to secure on behalf of the city the lowest and best bid
obtainable. (2010 Code § 6-2)
2-2-3: CONTRACT FOR PUBLIC IMPROVEMENTS:
A.   All contracts pertaining to public improvements, maintenance of public
improvements, maintenance of public property, public purchase of supplies and
all other contracts whatsoever character, involving an outlay as much as twenty
five thousand dollars ($25,000.00), or such number as may be enacted and
authorized by the state pursuant to the provisions of 61 Oklahoma Statutes
section 1 et seq., shall be made by the city commission and shall be based upon
the specifications provided by said commission. All such contracts shall be let
and awarded to the lowest responsible bidder, by free and open competitive
bidding after solicitation for sealed bids, and no work shall be commenced
until a written contract is executed. Advertising for bids and the subsequent
bidding process shall be conducted in compliance with section 4-2 of the city
charter.
B.   Perkins water and sewer trust contracts for construction, labor,
equipment, material or repairs in excess of twenty five thousand dollars
($25,000.00), or such number as may be enacted and authorized by the state,
shall be awarded by the trust to the lowest and best competitive bidder,
pursuant to public invitation to bid, which shall be published in the manner
provided in 60 Oklahoma Statutes section 176; provided, however, should the
trustees of the Perkins water and sewer trust find that an immediate emergency
exists, which findings shall be entered in the journal of the trust
proceedings, by reason of which an immediate outlay of trust funds in an amount
exceeding twenty five thousand dollars ($25,000.00) if necessary in order to
avoid loss of life, substantial damage to property, or damage to the public
peace or safety, then such contracts may be made and entered into without
public notice or competitive bids; provided, that the provisions of this
subsection shall not apply to contracts of industrial and cultural trusts.
(2010 Code § 6-3)
CHAPTER 3
SALE OF SURPLUS OR OBSOLETE PROPERTY
SECTION:
2-3-1: Sale Of Surplus Or Obsolete Property
2-3-1: SALE OF SURPLUS OR OBSOLETE PROPERTY:
A.   Value Determined Pursuant To Charter: Whenever the city manager concludes
to sell surplus, obsolete, abandoned or discarded supplies, materials and
equipment, or products or byproducts of the city, the city commission shall
determine the value thereof, pursuant to section 4-3 of the city charter.
B.   Competitive Bids Required: If the value of any article, or lot of articles
to be sold together, amounts to five hundred dollars ($500.00) or more, then
the city manager, or the city manager's designee, shall have the authority to:
   1.   Sell such article(s) to the highest bidder through a competitive
process, after due notice of inviting bids; or
   2.   Upon approval of the commission, to exchange or trade such article(s)
for new or reconditioned article(s) which have an equal or greater market
value, or to exchange such article(s) for services which have an equal or
greater market value and that will have a direct benefit to the city. A
statement of the reasons for such exchange shall be recorded with the office of
the city clerk.
C.   Auction: When it is practicable and advantageous for the city to utilize
an auction to sell surplus supplies, or a reverse auction to buy supplies,
services, or information technology systems, and when it meets the city's
objectives to do so, the city manager, or the city manager's designee, may
employ an auction or reverse auction process.
D.   Live Or Online Auction: Auctions or reverse auctions may be conducted
online, in person, or both at the same time. Auctions or reverse auctions may
be conducted live, with bidders competing in real time. Bidders' participation
in an auction or a reverse auction may be required as a step in another
competitive process.
E.   Exception: If the value of the item is less than five hundred dollars
($500.00), then such item may be sold without advertisement. (Ord. 441, 3-8-
2016)
CHAPTER 4
BUDGET
SECTION:
2-4-1: Municipal Budget; Adoption, Filing
2-4-2: Transfer Of Unexpended Or Unencumbered Appropriations
2-4-1: MUNICIPAL BUDGET; ADOPTION, FILING:
A.   Public Hearing: The city commission shall hold a public hearing on the
proposed budget no later than fifteen (15) days prior to the beginning of the
budget year. Notice of the date, time and place of the hearing, together with
the proposed budget summary, shall be published in a newspaper of general
circulation in the city not less than five (5) days before the date of the
hearing. The city clerk shall make available a sufficient number of copies of
the proposed budget as the city commission shall determine and have them
available for review or for distribution or sale at the office of the city
clerk. At the public hearing on the budget, any person may present to the city
commission comments, recommendations or information on any part of the proposed
budget.
B.   Adoption Of Budget: After the hearing and at least seven (7) days prior to
the beginning of the budget year, the city commission shall adopt the budget by
resolution. The city commission may add or increase items or delete or decrease
items in the budget. In all cases, the proposed expenditures shall not exceed
the estimated revenues for any fund.
C.   Filing Of Adopted Budget: The adopted budget shall be transmitted to the
state auditor and inspector and one copy shall be kept on file in the office of
the city clerk. A copy of the city sinking fund requirements shall be filed
with the excise board of Payne County.
D.   Effective Date: The adopted budget shall be in effect on and after the
first day of the fiscal year to which it applies. The budget as adopted and
filed with the state auditor and inspector shall constitute an appropriation
for each fund, and the appropriation thus made shall not be used for any other
purpose except as provided by law.
E.   Tax Levy: At the time required by law, the county excise board shall levy
the taxes necessary for the city sinking fund for the budget year pursuant to
62 Oklahoma Statutes section 431.
F.   Amendments: The city commission may amend the budget to make supplemental
appropriations to any fund up to the amount of additional revenues which are
available for current expenses for the fund due to:
   1.   Revenues received or to be received from sources not anticipated in the
budget for that year;
   2.   Revenues received or to be received from anticipated sources but in
excess of the budget estimates therefor;
   3.   Unexpended unencumbered cash balances on hand at the end of the
preceding fiscal year which had not been anticipated or appropriated in the
budget. Any appropriation authorizing the creating of an indebtedness shall be
governed by the application provisions of article 10 of the Oklahoma
constitution.
G.   Amendments Adopted, Filed: A budget amendment as provided in this section
authorizing supplemental appropriations or a decrease or change in
appropriation or funds shall be adopted at a meeting of the city commission and
filed with the city clerk and the state auditor and inspector. (2010 Code § 6-
5)
2-4-2: TRANSFER OF UNEXPENDED OR UNENCUMBERED APPROPRIATIONS:
A.   The city manager, or designee, as authorized by the governing body, may
transfer any unexpended and unencumbered appropriation, or any portion thereof,
from one account to another within the same department, or from one department
to another within the same fund, ("intrafund transfers"); except that no
appropriation for debt service or other appropriation required by law or
ordinance may be reduced below the minimums required. Any fund balance in an
enterprise fund of the city may be transferred to another fund of the city
("interfund transfers") as authorized by the city commission. Other interfund
transfers may be made only as adopted or amended according to 11 Oklahoma
Statutes section 17-206 or 17-216.
B.   All interfund transfers shall be made only in accordance with the
appropriations provided by the city commission for such transfers. Such
appropriations shall be contained in the original or amended budget of the
City. Once lawfully appropriated and approved by the city commission, interfund
transfer payments may be made by the city treasurer without further city
commission approval. Such transfers, however, may not exceed the amount
lawfully appropriated. The manner of payment of these interfund transfers shall
be consistent with the manner used for the payment of purchases of goods,
services, and capital as described in Section 2-8-3. The city treasurer shall
record or cause to be recorded these interfund transfers in the appropriate
journals and ledgers.
C.   No encumbrance or expenditure may be authorized or made by any officer or
employee which exceeds the available appropriations for each classification
level defined in 11 Oklahoma Statutes section 17-213. (2010 Code § 6-6; amd.
Ord. 513, 5-13-2025)
CHAPTER 5
FUNDING AND ACCOUNTING
SECTION:
2-5-1: Funds Established; Accounting
2-5-2: Sinking Fund
2-5-3: Service Fee For Dishonored Checks And ACH Debit Payments
2-5-4: Additional Fee For Accounts Sent To Collections
2-5-5: Additional Fee For Debit Or Credit Card Payments
2-5-1: FUNDS ESTABLISHED; ACCOUNTING:
The city shall establish funds consistent with legal and operating
requirements. The city shall maintain, according to its own needs, some or all
of the following funds or ledgers in its system of accounts:
A.   A general fund, to account for all monies received and disbursed for
general municipal government purposes, including all assets, liabilities,
reserves, fund balances, revenues and expenditures which are not accounted for
in any other fund or special ledger account. All monies received by the city
under the motor fuel tax or under the motor vehicle license and registration
tax and earmarked for the street and alley fund may be deposited in the general
fund and accounted for as a "street and alley account" within the general fund.
Expenditures from this account shall be made as earmarked and provided by law.
All references to the street and alley fund or to the special fund earmarked
for state shared gasoline and motor vehicle taxes may mean the street and alley
account provided in this section;
B.   Special revenue funds, as required, to account for the proceeds of
specific revenue sources that are restricted by law to expenditure for
specified purposes;
C.   Debt service fund, which shall include the municipal sinking fund,
established to account for the retirement of general obligation bonds or other
long term debt and payment of interest thereon and judgments as provided by
law. Any monies pledged to service general obligation bonds or other long term
debt must be deposited in the debt service fund;
D.   Capital project funds, to account for financial resources segregated for
acquisition, construction or other improvement related to capital facilities,
other than those accounted for in enterprise funds and nonexpendable trust
funds;
E.   Enterprise funds, to account for each utility or enterprise or other
service, other than those operated as a department of the general fund, where
the costs are financed primarily through user charges or where there is a
periodic need to determine revenues earned, expenses incurred or net income for
a service or program;
F.   Trust and agency funds, to account for assets held by the city as trustee
or agent for individual, private organizations or other governmental units or
purposes, such as retirement funds or a cemetery perpetual care fund;
G.   Internal service funds, to account for the financing of goods or services
provided by one department or agency of the city to another department or
agency, or to another government, on a cost reimbursement basis;
H.   A ledger or group of accounts in which to record the details relating to
the general fixed assets of the city;
I.   A ledger or group of accounts in which to record the details relating to
the general bonds or other long term debt of the city;
J.   Such other funds or ledgers as may be established by the city commission.
(2010 Code § 6-7)
2-5-2: SINKING FUND:
A.   It shall be the duty of the officers of the city to handle, deposit,
invest and use the money in the sinking fund of the city in the manner provided
by 62 Oklahoma Statutes sections 431 through 451, and any other applicable
provisions of law.
B.   The city clerk shall deposit daily all uninvested sinking fund money in
his hands in banks as provided by law. (2010 Code § 6-8; amd. 2012 Code)
2-5-3: SERVICE FEE FOR DISHONORED CHECKS AND ACH DEBIT PAYMENTS:
There shall be assessed and collected, in addition to any other penalties
provided by law, an administrative service fee as established by resolution of
the city commission on each check or ACH debit payment returned to the city by
reason of the refusal of the bank upon which such check or ACH debit payment
was drawn to honor the same; provided, in the event that two (2) such
dishonored checks or ACH debit payments are made to the city within any last
preceding twelve (12) month period, payment of any fee, fine, penalty or other
charge thereafter by the maker of such dishonored checks or ACH debit payments
shall be made and accepted only by a certified or cashier's check, or cash.
(Ord. 375, 5-11-2010; amd. 2012 Code)
2-5-4: ADDITIONAL FEE FOR ACCOUNTS SENT TO COLLECTIONS:
Pursuant to 11 Oklahoma Statutes section 22-138, the city authorizes a
collection fee, not to exceed thirty five percent (35%), to be added to all
debts, accounts receivable, court penalties, costs, fines, fees, penalties,
interest and other sums due the city that are turned over to a third party
collection agency. (Ord. 365, 3-9-2010)
2-5-5: ADDITIONAL FEE FOR DEBIT OR CREDIT CARD PAYMENTS:
A.   There shall be assessed and collected a debit or credit card service fee
in such amount as established by resolution of the city commission on each
manual or online transaction made to the city through any authorized bill pay
program for payment of utility bill, fee, fine, cost, penalty assessment,
donations, or other charge or collection.
B.   The service fee shall be limited to bank processing fees and financial
transaction fees, the cost of providing for secure transaction, portal fees,
and fees necessary to compensate for increased bandwidth incurred as a result
of providing for an online transaction. (Ord. 386, 4-12-2011; amd. 2012 Code;
Ord. 481, 11-12-2019)
CHAPTER 6
DEPOSIT OF FUNDS
SECTION:
2-6-1: Deposit Of Funds; Security
2-6-1: DEPOSIT OF FUNDS; SECURITY:
A.   Deposits: The funds of the city shall be deposited as required by law.
B.   Authority Of City Clerk: With approval of the city commission, the city
clerk shall have authority to deposit surplus funds of the city in his custody
in banks on a time deposit basis at the highest rate of interest obtainable for
such time deposit. (2010 Code § 6-9)
C.   Security: The deposits of the city shall be secured as required by state
law. (2010 Code § 6-9; amd. 2012 Code)
CHAPTER 7
CONFLICTS OF INTEREST IN CONTRACTS, LEASES PROHIBITED
SECTION:
2-7-1: Interests In City Contracts And Transactions
2-7-1: INTERESTS IN CITY CONTRACTS AND TRANSACTIONS:
A.   No member of the city commission may sell or furnish for a consideration,
any materials or supplies for use of the city; and any member of the commission
voting for, or consenting to, or being a party to, such contract or purchase is
personally liable as provided by 62 Oklahoma Statutes section 372.
B.   The city commission shall not make any contract with any of its members,
or in which any of its members shall be directly or indirectly interested, such
contracts being prohibited by 62 Oklahoma Statutes section 371.
C.   No officer of the city may become directly or indirectly interested
individually in any sale, lease or contract which he is authorized to make,
such being prohibited by 21 Oklahoma Statutes section 344. (2010 Code § 6-10)
CHAPTER 8
CLAIMS
SECTION:
2-8-1: Payroll Disbursements
2-8-2: Competitive Bidding
2-8-3: Purchases Of Goods, Services, And Capital
2-8-4: Debt Service
2-8-5: Petty Cash
2-8-6: Financial Reporting
2-8-7: Purchasing Requirement For Large Purposes
2-8-8: Incurring Indebtedness
2-8-9: Applicability To Public Trusts
2-8-1: PAYROLL DISBURSEMENTS:
A.   For all employees and officers of the City, a documented record shall be
maintained in a personnel file of the authorized rate of pay or salary and
authorized deductions for each employee or officer.
B.   For each pay period, a documented record of time worked and leave taken
shall be prepared, in the form of time sheets, cards or logs, for each employee
and officer to be paid. For employees exempt from the overtime provisions of
the Fair Labor Standards Act, the record may exclude time worked. Such record
of time worked and leave taken shall be verified as to its accuracy in writing
by the employee or officer and approved by the employee's/officer's supervisor.
C.   Upon verification of the work record, a payroll statement or register,
including the amount of gross pay, authorized deductions, and net pay, shall be
prepared and submitted to the City Manager for review and written approval.
D.   Upon approval of the payroll statement or register, the net payroll checks
or direct deposits shall be prepared along with checks, Automated Clearing
House, direct deposits, or wire transfers for payment of related payroll taxes
and other payroll benefits, required by law or contract.
E.   The checks or direct deposit report shall be presented to the City
Treasurer or designee along with the approved payroll statement or register.
The Treasurer shall compare the checks or direct deposits to the payroll
statement or register and verify their accuracy. Upon verification, two (2)
signers on the bank account shall sign any checks and prepare them for
distribution. In addition, the Treasurer shall prepare or caused to be prepared
a check or payment register.
F.   No payroll-related encumbrances are required to be recorded in the
budgetary accounting records as long as the payroll costs are recorded as
expenditures at the time they become due and payable. However, no payroll costs
may be incurred or paid if they exceed the available appropriation for the
purposes as established by the City Commission.
G.   The City Treasurer shall record or cause to be recorded in the appropriate
journals and ledgers the payroll costs incurred and/or paid for the pay period.
H.   A copy of the payroll statement, register or payroll check register may be
provided to the City Commission for informational purposes; however, the City
Commission approval is not required prior to the payment of payroll-related
costs if incurred and paid in accordance with the provisions above. (Ord. 513,
5-13-2025)
2-8-2: COMPETITIVE BIDDING:
A.   The City shall adhere to the provisions of Oklahoma Statutes (2001), Title
61, Sections 101 et seq. when determining when competitive bidding is required
and the manner in which competitive bids will be obtained.
B.   In addition to the requirements of A above, public trusts created pursuant
to O.S. Title 60, Section 176, of which the City is beneficiary, shall also
follow the competitive bidding provisions of Section 176(g) of Title 60. (Ord.
513, 5-13-2025)
2-8-3: PURCHASES OF GOODS, SERVICES, AND CAPITAL:
A.   The City Manager shall designate certain individuals as purchasing
officers empowered to purchase or contract against budget appropriations. Only
these designated individuals will be empowered to obligate the City.
B.   For all purchases of goods, services or capital (all purchases or
disbursements other than payroll and debt service), purchase orders or
contracts shall be prepared and approved, in writing, by a designated
purchasing officer prior to the time the purchase commitment is made. The
approved purchase order or contract shall be forwarded to an officer or
employee charged with keeping the appropriation and expenditure records
(encumbering clerk) who shall determine that there exists available
unencumbered appropriation for that purpose. Upon such determination, the
encumbering clerk shall attest to that fact in writing. If appropriation is not
available for the proposed purchase or commitment, the purchase or commitment
shall not proceed until budget amendments are authorized to provide sufficient
appropriation. Upon approval of the purchasing officer and encumbering clerk,
an encumbrance shall be recorded in the appropriation and expenditure records
in the amount or estimated amount of the commitment.
   These encumbering requirements shall not apply to the following type of
purchases or commitments:
   1.   Payroll and payroll-related expenses;
   2.   Utility and telephone services by entities governed by State
Corporation Commission;
   3.   Insurance and employee benefits contracts.
C.   For all purchases or contracts for goods, services or capital over twenty
five thousand dollars ($25,000.00), City Commission approval shall be obtained
prior to the time the commitment is made, and such approval shall be recorded
in the minutes of the Commission. Single purchases for a price of twenty-five
thousand dollars ($25,000.00) or less may be made by the City Manager in
compliance with Code Section
2-2-1 and shall not require City Commission approval.
D.   After satisfactory delivery of the merchandise or completion of contract
provisions, an invoice or claim form shall be obtained adequately documenting
request for payment. The officer or employee receiving satisfactory delivery of
merchandise or contract service shall acknowledge such fact by signing the
invoice, claim form, delivery ticket or receiving advice.
   The invoice or claim form, along with the written acknowledgment of receipt,
shall be forwarded to the officer or employee responsible for processing
accounts payable who shall review the invoice for accuracy and propriety,
including comparison to the authorized purchase order or contract, if
applicable.
   Upon completion of the accounts payable officer review, the invoice or claim
form along with the related supporting documentation shall be submitted to the
City Manager or designee for consideration by, and the written approval of, the
City Manager or designee. All invoices or claim forms approved for payment by
the City Manager or designee shall be paid upon certification of the invoices
or claim forms by the City Manager or designee.
E.   Upon approval of the invoices or claims for payment by the City Manager,
checks, wire transfers, Automated Clearing House, or other payment documents as
authorized by State law (11 O.S., Section 17-102) shall be prepared and
submitted to the City Treasurer or designee, along with copies of the approved
invoices or claim forms.
   The Treasurer or designee shall compare the payment documents to the invoice
or claim form and verify their accuracy. Upon verification, two (2) signers on
the bank account shall sign the checks or other documents. In addition, the
Treasurer shall prepare or cause to be prepared a check or disbursement
register and shall distribute or cause to be distributed the payments.
F.   The City Treasurer shall record or cause to be recorded in the appropriate
journals and ledgers the purchases and cash disbursements incurred and paid.
G.   The city, in compliance with state statute, may issue a blanket purchase
order for any recurring purchases of goods or services if a maximum authorized
amount for all purchases pursuant to a blanket purchase order is specified in
the order and approved by the city commission. (Ord. 513, 5-13-2025)
2-8-4: DEBT SERVICE:
A.   All long-term indebtedness, in the form of bonds, notes or lease purchase
obligations, shall be incurred only in the manner provided by law.
B.   Once lawfully incurred, payments of principal and interest on the bonds or
notes and payments on the lease purchase obligations shall be paid in
accordance with the terms as specified in the bond indenture, note agreement or
lease purchase contract by the City Treasurer without further approval of the
governing body.
C.   The manner of payment shall be consistent with the manner used for the
payment of purchases of goods, services, or capital as described in Section 2-
8-3 above.
D.   The City Treasurer shall record or cause to be recorded in the appropriate
journals and ledgers the debt service payments and maintain current records of
the remaining amount of indebtedness. (Ord. 513, 5-13-2025)
2-8-5: PETTY CASH:
A.   As provided for in 11 O.S., Section 17-102(D) of the Oklahoma State
Statutes, the City may have petty cash accounts for use in making certain small
payments for costs incurred in operating the municipality.
B.   Each petty cash account established shall require City Commission
approval, including the amount of the petty cash imprest balance. However, in
no case, should the imprest balance exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00).
C.   The petty cash accounts shall be reimbursed by utilizing properly itemized
invoices or petty cash voucher slips and by then processing the reimbursement
in the manner used for payment of purchases of goods, services, and capital.
(Ord. 513, 5-13-2025)
2-8-6: FINANCIAL REPORTING:
The City Treasurer, or their designee, shall prepare a monthly budget status
report in accordance with a comparison of actual results to date and the budget
by purpose. The report shall be placed on the Agenda for City Commission
acknowledgment at a meeting of the City Commission in the month following the
close of the monthly period. (Ord. 513, 5-13-2025)
2-8-7: PURCHASING REQUIREMENT FOR LARGE PURPOSES:
The purchase of any property, real or personal, or the acquisition of any
interest therein the value of which property, lease, or interest is greater
than an amount equal to four percent (4%) of the City of Perkins general fund
budget for the most immediate prior fiscal year budget or the amount of sixty
five thousand dollars ($65,000.00) whichever amount is smaller shall be made
only in accordance with Section 4-5 of the City of Perkins Charter. (Ord. 513,
5-13-2025)
2-8-8: INCURRING INDEBTEDNESS:
As provided for in Article 10, Section 26 of the Oklahoma Constitution, the
City is prohibited from becoming indebted in any manner for any purpose in an
amount exceeding the amount appropriated by the City Commission for such
purpose, without voter approval. (Ord. 513, 5-13-2025)
2-8-9: APPLICABILITY TO PUBLIC TRUSTS:
For all public trusts created pursuant to 60 O.S., Sections 176-180, for which
the City is beneficiary and for which the trust's governing body (Trustees) are
comprised entirely of members of the City Commission, the requirements of
Sections
2-8-1 through
2-8-6 above shall apply. For the purposes of the public trusts, as used above,
the trust's governing body shall mean board of trustees of the trust, City
Manager shall mean Trust Manager as appointed by the trustees, and City
Treasurer shall mean Trust Treasurer as appointed by the trustees or required
by the trust indenture. (Ord. 513, 5-13-2025)
CHAPTER 9
WARRANTS; DISBURSEMENT OF FUNDS
SECTION:
2-9-1: Warrants; Disbursement Of Funds
2-9-1: WARRANTS; DISBURSEMENT OF FUNDS:
A.   Statute Authority: Warrants shall be issued and processed, and funds of
the city disbursed, only for legal purposes and in accordance with 62 Oklahoma
Statutes sections 471 through 485, and 11 Oklahoma Statutes section 17-102.
(2010 Code § 6-13; amd. Ord. 513, 5-13-2025)
CHAPTER 10
BONDS; ISSUANCE AND SALE
SECTION:
2-10-1: Bonds; Issuance And Sale
2-10-1: BONDS; ISSUANCE AND SALE:
Bonds of the city shall be issued, sold, paid and handled in all respects as
provided by 62 Oklahoma Statutes section 351 et seq., and other applicable
provisions of law. (2010 Code § 6-14)
CHAPTER 11
EXAMINATION AND AUDIT OF BOOKS AND RECORDS
SECTION:
2-11-1: Examination And Audit Of Books And Records
2-11-1: EXAMINATION AND AUDIT OF BOOKS AND RECORDS:
A.   Authority: The books of the city clerk shall be subject to examination by
the city commission at all times, as provided by 11 Oklahoma Statutes section
17-105. Likewise, the records of all other officers and employees of the city
shall be subject to inspection by the city commission at all times, subject to
the confidentiality requirements of each department.
B.   Public Accountant Designated: The city commission shall designate a
qualified public accountant to audit the financial records and transactions of
the city clerk and all other personnel of the city who keep financial records
and make financial transactions, as of the end of every fiscal year at least,
and such accountant shall make such audit and shall report to the city
commission and to such other officer or governmental entity as may be required
by the Oklahoma Statutes.
C.   Perkins Water And Sewer Trust: The city commission shall cause an audit to
be performed not less than annually of the books and financial records of the
Perkins water and sewer trust and such audit shall be reported to the city
commission and to such other office or governmental entity as may be required
by the Oklahoma Statutes.
D.   Statute Requirements: All audit reports made and given to the city
commission shall comply with the requirements of 11 Oklahoma Statutes section
17-106.1.
E.   Publication: The city commission shall cause there to be published, within
thirty (30) days of receipt of the annual audit reports, a notice of
availability for public inspection the audit reports of the city and the
Perkins water and sewer trust. (2010 Code § 6-15)
CHAPTER 12
INSURANCE
SECTION:
2-12-1: Property, Vehicle Insurance
2-12-1: PROPERTY, VEHICLE INSURANCE:
A.   The city commission may insure property of the city as authorized by 11
Oklahoma Statutes section 23-101, and 19 Oklahoma Statutes section 627. Any
money received as a result of destruction, damage or loss of such insured
property shall be accounted for and used as provided by said sections. (2010
Code § 6-16)
B.   The city commission may purchase insurance to pay damage to persons
sustaining injuries or damages to property as a result of negligent operation
of motor vehicle or motorized equipment of the city, as authorized by Oklahoma
Statutes. (2010 Code § 6-16; amd. 2012 Code)
CHAPTER 13
TAXES
ARTICLE A. SALES TAX
SECTION:
2-13A-1: Citation And Codification
2-13A-2: Definitions
2-13A-3: Tax Collector Defined
2-13A-4: Classification Of Taxpayers
2-13A-5: Subsisting State Permits
2-13A-6: Effective Date
2-13A-7: Purpose Of Revenues
2-13A-8: Tax Rate; Sales Subject To Tax
2-13A-8-1: Additional Excise Tax (Sales Tax) For Public Safety Departments
2-13A-8-2: Sales Tax Code
2-13A-8-3: Additional Excise Tax (Sales Tax) For the Perkins Public Library
2-13A-9: Exemptions
2-13A-10: Tax Due When; Returns; Records
2-13A-11: Payment Of Tax; Brackets
2-13A-12: Tax Constitutes Debt
2-13A-13: Vendor's Duty To Collect Tax
2-13A-14: Returns And Remittances; Discounts
2-13A-15: Interest And Penalties; Delinquency
2-13A-16: Waiver Of Interest And Penalties
2-13A-17: Erroneous Payments; Claim For Refund
2-13A-18: Fraudulent Returns; Penalty
2-13A-19: Records Confidential
2-13A-20: Amendments
2-13A-21: Provisions Cumulative
2-13A-1: CITATION AND CODIFICATION:
This article shall be known and shall be cited as the CITY OF PERKINS SALES TAX
ORDINANCE. (2010 Code § 6-17)
2-13A-2: DEFINITIONS:
Unless specified otherwise herein, the definitions of words, terms and phrases
contained in the Oklahoma sales tax code, 68 Oklahoma Statutes section 1351 et
seq., are hereby adopted by reference and made a part of this article.
In addition to the definitions contained herein and in 68 Oklahoma Statutes
section 1352, the term "gross receipts" shall also include the total retail
sale price received for the sale, preparation or service of mixed beverages,
ice and nonalcoholic beverages to be mixed with alcoholic beverages for
consumption on the premises where such sale, preparation and service occurs
shall constitute the gross receipts from such transaction. (2010 Code § 6-18)
2-13A-3: TAX COLLECTOR DEFINED:
The term "tax collector", as used herein, means the department of the city
government or the official agency of the state duly designated according to law
or contract authorized by law to administer the collection of the tax herein
levied. (2010 Code § 6-19)
2-13A-4: CLASSIFICATION OF TAXPAYERS:
For the purpose of this article, the classification of taxpayers hereunder
shall be as prescribed by state law for purposes of the Oklahoma sales tax
code. (2010 Code § 6-20)
2-13A-5: SUBSISTING STATE PERMITS:
All valid and subsisting permits to do business issued by the Oklahoma tax
commission pursuant to the Oklahoma sales tax code are, for the purpose of this
article, hereby ratified, confirmed and adopted in lieu of any requirement for
an additional city permit for the same purpose. (2010 Code § 6-21)
2-13A-6: EFFECTIVE DATE:
This article shall become and be effective on and after April 1, 1971, unless
otherwise amended. (2010 Code § 6-22)
2-13A-7: PURPOSE OF REVENUES:
It is hereby declared to be the purpose of this article that the first two
percent (2%) tax levied shall be for providing revenues for the support of the
functions of the municipal government of the city of Perkins, Oklahoma, and
that the remaining one percent (1%) shall be providing revenues for the purpose
of directly funding the costs of acquiring, remodeling, renovating, maintaining
and constructing the city library facilities, repairing and extending the water
supply and distribution system, constructing additional water storage
facilities, improving and extending the sanitary sewer system, acquiring,
remodeling, renovating, maintaining and constructing the fire department
facilities and/or equipment, resurfacing, repairing, paving and improving
limited access facilities of said city and to acquire equipment to be utilized
for any of the purposes stated above and/or to deposit such revenues in the
sinking fund of the city to be used to pay the principal and interest
requirements on the general obligation bonds and/or loans issued by said city
for any or all of the purposes above stated. After satisfaction of the above
purposes, revenues from the sales tax shall be deposited in the general fund of
the city of Perkins to be used for capital improvements. (Ord. 413, 1-14-2014)
2-13A-8: TAX RATE; SALES SUBJECT TO TAX:
There is hereby levied an excise tax of three percent (3%) upon the gross
proceeds or gross receipts derived from all sales taxable under the sales tax
law of Oklahoma, as specified in 68 Oklahoma Statutes section 1354. (2010 Code
§ 6-24; amd. 2012 Code)
2-13A-8-1:   ADDITIONAL EXCISE TAX (SALES TAX) FOR PUBLIC SAFETY DEPARTMENTS:
There is hereby imposed an excise tax of one-half of one percent (1/2%) in
addition to any and all other excise tax which is now in force to be levied
upon the gross proceeds or receipts derived from all sales taxable under the
Oklahoma sales tax code. The purpose of this tax is to provide revenues for the
purpose of constructing, improving, repairing, and/or operating and maintaining
existing, as well as new fire, police and emergency management facilities and
equipment in the city, and/or for the payment of debt service in connection
with obligations issued to finance said facilities and equipment. One-eighth of
one percent (1/8%) of the excise tax provided for hereby shall terminate on
June 30, 2020. (Ord. 402, 6-11-2013)
2-13A-8-2: SALES TAX CODE:
Additional One Quarter of One Percent (1/4%) Excise Tax (Sales Tax) for capital
improvements and operations expenses for Perkins Parks and Recreational
facilities.
A.   A limited-term excise tax (sales tax) in the amount of one quarter of one
percent (1/4%) is hereby levied upon the gross proceeds or gross receipts
derived from all sales taxable under the sales tax laws of the state of
Oklahoma.
B.   The limited-term excise tax levied pursuant to Section
2-13A-8-2  above may be expended only for the limited purpose of providing
revenues for the general operations, programming, and Capital Improvements to
Perkins Parks and Recreational facilities.
c.   For purposes of this Section, "Capital Improvements" shall mean without
limitation any one or more of the following:
   1.   The acquisition of real or personal properties or any interests therein
or appurtenances thereto; and/or
   2.   The construction, reconstruction, demolition, installation, assembly,
renovation, repairing, remodeling, restoring, furbishing, refurbishing,
furnishing, refurnishing, equipping, reequipping, or maintenance of the Perkins
Parks and Recreational building(s), structures, fixtures, or personal
properties or on any park or recreational real properties or interests therein
or appurtenances thereto; and/or
   3.   Any other type of beneficial or valuable change or addition,
betterment, enhancement, or amelioration of or upon any real property, or any
interest therein or appurtenances thereto, belonging to the City of Perkins,
intended to enhance its value, beauty, or utility or to adapt it to new or
further purposes.
D.   Expenditures to provide capital improvements under this section may
include expenditures for any or all items, articles, costs, or expenses related
in any way to provide parks and recreational facilities capital improvement,
including without limitation the following:
   1.   Payments of the costs of acquiring real or personal properties or
interests therein and appurtenances thereto;
   2.   Payments of the costs of construction, reconstruction, demolition,
installation, assembly, renovation, repairing, remodeling, restoring,
furbishing, refurbishing, furnishing, refurnishing, equipping, reequipping, and
maintenance;
   3.   Payment of architectural costs, engineering costs, or consulting costs;
   4.   Payments of project management costs, administrative costs, and legal
costs;
   5.   Payment of any other items, articles, costs or expenses related,
incidental, or ancillary in any way to providing parks and recreational
facilities capital improvements;
   6.   Reimbursements or paybacks for expenditure made by a public trust with
the City as its beneficiary for the purpose of providing parks and recreational
facilities capital improvement, and/or
   7.   If deemed necessary or appropriate by the City Council for cash-flow
purposes, for the payment of principal and interest on and the costs of
issuance of bonds, notes, or other evidences of indebtedness issued by a public
trust with the City as its beneficiary for the purpose of providing a parks and
recreational facilities capital improvements.
E.   For purposes of this Section, "General Operations" shall mean without
limitation any of the general operations, programming, or other expenses or
costs of the Perkins Parks and Recreational Facilities, specifically including
but not limited to salaries, maintenance of facilities and real property, costs
of programs, and other expenditures related to the ordinary operations of the
city's parks and recreation department.
F.   Pursuant to the authority of 68 O.S. § 2701(B) there is hereby created a
limited-purpose fund to be known as the "Perkins Parks and Recreational
Facilities Capital Improvements Sales Tax Fund" (hereinafter, the "Fund") into
which all revenues collected pursuant to this Section shall be accumulated from
year-to-year. The Fund shall be placed in an insured interest-bearing account
and the interest that accumulates on the Fund shall be retained in the Fund.
The Fund shall be non-fiscal and shall not be considered in any computations of
the City for needed appropriations. Monies in the Fund shall be expended only
as accumulated and only for the limited purpose specified above.
G.   The excise tax (sales tax) levied pursuant to Section
2-13A-8-2  above shall be for a limited term of ten (10) years, beginning at
twelve o’clock (12:00) a.m. on July 1, 2024 and terminating at twelve o’clock
(12:00) a.m on June 30, 2034.
H.   As used in this Section, the word "City" shall mean the City of Perkins,
Payne County, Oklahoma, a municipal corporation, and/or any public trust with
the City as its beneficiary.
I.   The limited-term excise tax (sales tax) levied pursuant to this Section
2-13A-8-2  shall be cumulative to all other excise taxes (sales taxes)
currently levied by the City on gross proceeds or gross receipts derived from
all sales taxable under the sales tax laws of the State of Oklahoma. (Ord. 496,
11-14-2023)
2-13A-8-3: ADDITIONAL EXCISE TAX (SALES TAX) FOR THE PERKINS PUBLIC LIBRARY:
Section 2-13A-8-3: Additional Excise Tax (Sales Tax) For the Perkins Public
Library:
There is hereby imposed an additional one quarter of one percent (1/4%) Excise
Tax (Sales Tax) for capital improvements and operations expenses for the
Perkins Public Library.
A.   A limited-term excise tax (sales tax) in the amount of one quarter of one
percent (1/4%) is hereby levied upon the gross proceeds or gross receipts
derived from all sales taxable under the sales tax laws of the State of
Oklahoma.
B.   The limited-term excise tax levied pursuant to Section
2-13A-8-3  above may be expended only for the limited purpose of providing
revenues for the General Operations of and Capital Improvements to the Perkins
Public Library.
C.   For purposes of this Section, "Capital Improvements" shall mean without
limitation any one (1) or more of the following:
   1.   The acquisition of real or personal properties or any interests therein
or appurtenances thereto; and/ or
   2.   The construction, reconstruction, demolition, installation, assembly,
renovation, repairing, remodeling, restoring, furbishing, refurbishing,
furnishing, refurnishing, equipping, reequipping, or maintenance of the Perkins
Public Library building(s), structures, fixtures, or personal properties or on
any Library real properties or interests therein or appurtenances thereto; and/
or
   3.   Any other type of beneficial or valuable change or addition,
betterment, enhancement, or amelioration of or upon any real property, or any
interest therein or appurtenances thereto, belonging to the Library, intended
to enhance its value, beauty, or utility or to adapt it to new or further
purposes.
D.   Expenditures to provide Library capital improvements under this Section
may include expenditures for any or all items, articles, costs, or expenses
related in any way to provide Library capital improvements, including without
limitation the following:
   1.   Payments of the costs of acquiring real or personal properties or
interests therein and appurtenances thereto;
   2.   Payments of the costs of construction, reconstruction, demolition,
installation, assembly, renovation, repairing, remodeling, restoring,
furbishing, refurbishing, furnishing, refurnishing, equipping, reequipping, and
maintenance;
   3.   Payment of architectural costs, engineering costs, or consulting costs;
   4.   Payments of project management costs, administrative costs, and legal
costs;
   5.   Payment of any other items, articles, costs or expenses related,
incidental, or ancillary in any way to providing library capital improvements;
   6.   Reimbursements or paybacks for expenditure made by a public trust with
the city as its beneficiary for the purpose of providing a library capital
improvement; and/ or
   7.   If deemed necessary or appropriate by the City Commission for cash-flow
purposes, for the payment of principal and interest on and the costs of
issuance of bonds, notes, or other evidences of indebtedness issued by a public
trust with the City as its beneficiary for the purpose of providing a Library
capital improvement.
E.   For purposes of this Section, "General Operations" shall mean without
limitation any of the general operations, programming, or other expenses or
costs of the Perkins Public Library, specifically including but not limited to
salaries, maintenance of facilities and real property, costs of programs, and
other expenditures related to the ordinary operations of the Perkins Public
Library.
F.   Pursuant to the authority of 68 O.S. § 2701(B) there is hereby created a
limited-purpose fund to be known as the "Perkins Public Library Capital
Improvements Sales Tax Fund" (hereinafter, the "Fund") into which all revenues
collected pursuant to this Section shall be accumulated from year-to-year. The
Fund shall be placed in an insured interest-bearing account and the interest
that accumulates on the Fund shall be retained in the Fund. The Fund shall be
non-fiscal and shall not be considered in any computations of the City for
needed appropriations. Monies in the Fund shall be expended only as accumulated
and only for the limited purpose specified above.
G.   The excise tax (sales tax) levied pursuant to Section 2-13A-8-3 above
shall be for a limited term of ten (10) years, beginning at twelve o’clock (12:
00) a.m. on July 1, 2024 and terminating at twelve o’clock (12:00) a.m on June
30, 2034.
H.   As used in this section, the word "City" shall mean the City of Perkins,
Payne County, Oklahoma, a municipal corporation, and/ or any public trust with
the City as its beneficiary.
I.   The limited-term excise tax (sales tax) levied pursuant to this Section
shall be cumulative to all other excise taxes (sales taxes) currently levied by
the City on gross proceeds or gross receipts derived from all sales taxable
under the sales tax laws of the State of Oklahoma. (Ord. 495, 11-14-2023)
2-13A-9:EXEMPTIONS:
Exemptions from the sales tax levied herein shall be allowed pursuant to
Oklahoma Statutes. (2010 Code § 6-25; amd. 2012 Code)
2-13A-10:TAX DUE WHEN; RETURNS; RECORDS:
The tax levied hereunder shall be due and payable at the time and in the manner
and form prescribed for payment of the state sales tax under the sales tax law
of the state. (2010 Code § 6-27)
2-13A-11:PAYMENT OF TAX; BRACKETS:
A.   The tax herein levied shall be paid to the tax collector at the time and
in the form and manner provided for payment of state sales tax under the sales
tax law of Oklahoma.
B.   The bracket system for the collection of the three percent (3%) city sales
tax by the tax collector shall be as the same is hereinafter adopted by the
agreement of the city and the tax collector, in the collection of both the
three percent (3%) city sales tax and the three and one-fourth percent (31/4%)
state sales tax. (2010 Code § 6-28)
2-13A-12:TAX CONSTITUTES DEBT:
Such taxes, penalty and interest due hereunder shall at all times constitute a
prior, superior and paramount claim as against the claims of unsecured
creditors, and may be collected by suit as any other debt. (2010 Code § 6-29)
2-13A-13:VENDOR'S DUTY TO COLLECT TAX:
   A.   The tax levied hereunder shall be paid by the consumer or user to the
vendor, and it shall be the duty of each and every vendor in this city to
collect from the consumer or user the full amount of the tax levied under this
article, or an amount equal as nearly as possible or practicable to the average
equivalent thereof.
   B.   Vendors shall add the tax imposed hereunder, or the average equivalent
thereof, to the sales price or charge, and when added, such tax shall
constitute a part of such price or charge, shall be a debt from the consumer or
user to the vendor until paid, and shall be recoverable at law in the same
manner as other debts. (2010 Code § 6-30)
   C.   A vendor, as defined herein, who wilfully or intentionally fails,
neglects or refuses to collect the full amount of the tax levied under this
article, or wilfully or intentionally fails, neglects or refuses to comply with
the provisions of remits or rebates to a consumer or user, either directly or
indirectly, and by whatsoever means, all or any part of the tax herein levied,
or makes in any form of advertising, verbally or otherwise, any statement which
infers that he is absorbing the tax, or paying the tax for the consumer or user
by an adjustment of prices or at a price including the tax, or in any manner
whatsoever shall be deemed guilty of an offense and, upon conviction thereof,
shall be subject to penalty as provided in section
1-4-1  of this code. (2010 Code § 6-30; amd. 2012 Code)
2-13A-14:RETURNS AND REMITTANCES; DISCOUNTS:
Returns and remittances of the tax herein levied and collected shall be made to
the tax collector at the time and in the manner, form and amount as prescribed
for returns and remittances required by the state sales tax code; and
remittances of tax collected hereunder shall be subject to the same discount as
may be allowed by said code for collection of state sales taxes. (2010 Code §
6-31)
2-13A-15:INTEREST AND PENALTIES; DELINQUENCY:
68 Oklahoma Statutes section 217 is hereby adopted and made a part of this
article, and interest and penalties at the rates and in amounts as therein
specified are hereby levied and shall be applicable in cases of delinquency in
reporting and paying the tax levied by this article; provided, that the failure
or refusal of any taxpayer to make and transmit the reports and remittances of
tax in the time and manner required by this article shall cause such tax to be
delinquent. In addition, if such delinquency continues for a period of five (5)
days, the taxpayer shall forfeit his claim to any discount allowed under this
article. (2010 Code § 6-32)
2-13A-16:WAIVER OF INTEREST AND PENALTIES:
The interest or penalty, or any portion thereof, accruing by reason of a
taxpayer's failure to pay the city tax herein levied may be waived or remitted
in the same manner as provided for said waiver or remittance as applied in
administration of the state sales tax provided in 68 Oklahoma Statutes section
220, and to accomplish the purposes of this section, the applicable provisions
of said section 220 are hereby adopted by reference and made a part of this
article. (2010 Code § 6-33)
2-13A-17:ERRONEOUS PAYMENTS; CLAIM FOR REFUND:
Refund or erroneous payment of the city sales tax herein levied may be made to
any taxpayer making such erroneous payment in the same manner and procedure,
and under the same limitation of time, as provided for administration of the
state sales tax as set forth in 68 Oklahoma Statutes section 227, and to
accomplish the purposes of this section, the applicable provisions of said
section 227 are hereby adopted by reference and made a part of this article.
(2010 Code § 6-34)
2-13A-18:FRAUDULENT RETURNS; PENALTY:
In addition to all civil penalties provided by this article, the wilful failure
or refusal of any taxpayer to make reports and remittances herein required, or
the making of any false and fraudulent report for the purpose of avoiding or
escaping payment of any tax or portion thereof rightfully due under this
article shall be an offense and, upon conviction thereof, the offending
taxpayer shall be subject to penalty as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code. (2010 Code § 6-35; amd. 2012 Code)
2-13A-19:RECORDS CONFIDENTIAL:
The confidential and privileged nature of the records and files concerning the
administration of the city sales tax is legislatively recognized and declared
and to protect the same, the provisions of 68 Oklahoma Statutes section 205 of
the state sales tax code, and each subsection thereof, is hereby adopted by
reference and made fully effective and applicable to administration of the city
sales tax as if herein set forth in full. (2010 Code § 6-36)
2-13A-20:AMENDMENTS:
The people of the city, by their approval of this tax at the election, herein
authorize the board of commissioners by ordinance duly enacted to make such
administrative and technical changes or additions in the method and manner of
administration and enforcing this tax as may be necessary or proper for
efficiency and fairness, except that the rate of the tax herein provided shall
not be changed without approval of the qualified electors of the city as
provided by law. (2010 Code § 6-37)
2-13A-21:PROVISIONS CUMULATIVE:
The provisions hereof shall be cumulative, and in addition to any and all other
taxing provisions of the city ordinances. (2010 Code § 6-38)
ARTICLE B. USE TAX
SECTION:

Property Levied
